pros: They have good benefits, and usually will move you up in the company if you want to.

I took over a position, and they offered me 9k less than the previous employe, despite the stores sales being better than ever. I should've taken the job offer at a competitor who would've started me at 5k higher than SW's offer.

pros: There are a lot of good people in this company.  Good benefits.  Decent income.
cons:
The job has become nearly impossible.  Many goals are purposely set at unreachable levels.
After working 50 plus hours per week for many, many years, always giving my all and providing the best customer service; missing fewer days of work than I have years of service, walking the stage(sales awards) 5 times and having many strong years in between,building customer loyalty at each of seven stores I have run in four states, I just had my work ethic listed as not meeting standards on an appraisal.Not just my work ethic, but every aspect of the job. Oh, and I am 20% up in sales for the year and $24000 over budget in profit.  To someone who has worked as hard as I have for all these years there is no greater insult.  There is no one in this company who has worked harder than I have
over a quarter century.  SW should be ashamed of itself to treat its "valued" employees like this.   (I am not the only one)  Retirement is six years away.  No idea how I will hang on that long, but I'll give it my best like I always have.   It seems the job is now designed to drive people to the point of total burn-out in an effort to maximize productivity.  Flawed logic.

 I have lost all respect for this company and those I work for.  I have the greatest respect for those I work with.  
If ONLY I could try just a little bit harder.

job_title: Assistant Store Manager in Indianapolis, IN
pros: Structured training and paths for career development. If you are willing to come in and work hard from day 1, you will be recognized for those efforts and the management team is in place to help promote you as opportunities come available. In larger districts there seems to be a lot of growth as employees move from store to store and into a sales rep position. Additionally the company produces a product you feel proud to stand behind. When customers are disappointed they want you to do what you can at the store level to make things right even if it's at their own expense.
cons: In store jobs are very physically demanding. Despite the company's focus on women's initiatives there were days when I would need to shake over 300 gallons of paint by myself in less than an hour. Given that I only weigh 130 lbs and a 5-gal bucket of paint can easily weigh 50-80 lbs this was exhausting and probably has caused long-term back problems. The stores are also allotted staffing budgets that never seem to be enough. Managers were once allowed to go over as long as they were willing to receive the penalty with their bonus structure, but district managers were starting to cut that out.

review_title: Sherwin-Williams - A great place to work!
pros: Working at Sherwin-Willams HQ, job security is excellent overall.  They are also fairly flexible with schedules and provide reimbursement for certifications and college coursework - both of which are often important to young professionals as well as managers looking to advance thru MBA programs.  On the business side, the culture is very lean and efficient, while on the IT side things are run much like a mom and pop shop at times - this allows a lot of freedom and leeway in how you accomplish goals and learn new things.  People are generally warm and open to answering questions and sharing their knowledge.
cons: Sherwin-Williams is an old fashioned manufacturing company.  They are an enormous global enterprise.  With those things naturally comes baggage like bureaucracy and resistance to change - a lot of processes are in place to provide organization and control. Though these often help in providing a consistent environment across the enterprise, they also often hinder new exciting benefits and getting seemingly simple tasks pushed through the system. You won't find the flexibility or total freedom you find working for smaller employers.  In summary, they are somewhat monolithic in their standards and old-fashioned in their procedures - you will need to be able to work within these corporate traits in order to successfully move things forward and impact change in the enterprise in the future.

pros: Good benefits package, compensation is relatively competitive with good bonus plan (dependent on the store however), well respected company
cons: Hours cut which means less employees; at the same time, upper management continued to assign meaningless sales call goals and promotional activities that you had no time to do. 40% off sales at least once a month but not enough employees to assist during the sale. Price increases and lack of customer service (again to due hour cuts) just led to dissatisfied customers. The glamorized "Management Trainee Program" is just a way for the company to get a bunch of workhorses with college degrees to put in their stores. On a daily basis the job consisted of about 80% physical work - tinting paint, lifting, operating forklifts, etc. with very little time to actually manage (which is what I was told I would be doing when I was interviewed). Very little opportunities for advancement. Expect to work in the store for about 4 or 5 years on average and then get "promoted" to being a sales rep which is just another unrewarding job where you get to deal with more stress. Gave it a year, but couldn't come to terms with having a job that provided absolutely no intellectual stimulation. I didn't go to college to mix paint all day and get chewed out by completely irrational, overemotional, and psychotic customers.

Long, long, long hours.  Early mornings, late nights, weekends, holidays, you name it.  It's non stop.  And even when you are "off", you're not truly off.  Especially as a store manager.  I constantly got phone calls from my employees, my city manager, my customers, my sales reps.  It was never ending. Yes, there is bonus "opportunity" but it is nearly impossible to get. When I started with the company, you did your job, you hit your numbers, you got your bonus.  By the time I left 8 years later, it was impossible.  The pay was pathetic unless you hit your numbers, too.  

Witnessed very, very poor support for a lot of the female employees that worked with, specifically the ones who wanted to have families. 

Unless you have NO life, and don't want to have a life outside of work, don't come work for this company.  The best decision I could have made was to find a different job with a company that supported it's employees ideals, ambitions, and just it's employees as individuals.  Because SW was NOT it in the slightest.

Long hours! Consistently looking to push store hours and cut labor. 
They will tell you that they do not micro manage, but they take micro managing to a whole new level. 
Constant sales initiatives that the consumer has grown to expect, making it next to impossible to sell paint at an everyday price. 
Lack of creativity in sales initiatives. Same initiative  every 3-4 months with diminishing returns. For example new account drive. Push for new accounts throughout the year, leaving nothing but low potential accounts behind with the expectation that those low potential accounts grow into profitably heavy hitters. 
There is a good ole boy network within some districts. 
Big diversity push, which is great, but they are promoting based solely on gender and popularity rather than skill set and achievement. 
Last but not least, roommates when you travel!! If you can’t afford to provide me with the privacy I expect while on the road, then don’t send me. And do not tell me that it is team building. I’m a grown man, and have the ability to build a relationship with a stranger without sharing a budget hotel room with them.

review_title: Changing of the Guard at SW
pros: SW has historically been a solid stable blue chip company with a long successful history. Was a great place to work for years.
cons:
The Company has new leadership and has recently implemented "new sales methodologies" for obtaining business/accounts. The store managers are now charged with trespassing and "accosting" prospective customers in our competitors (such as Home Depot and Lowes) parking lots. 

First, this takes precious time away from mission critical management and sales responsibilities at the SW retail store. As a result of this newly proposed compulsory activity - leadership has also implemented a new quota system for store managers that is completely unrealistic and well just not doable -- EVEN if these practices were not unethical, embarrassing and undoubtedly illegal! 

Where is HR? They should be doing their job -- warning and advising leadership against  this potentially illegal practice affectionately called "Seal Island" by SW exec leadership. This is a stealth exercise is where the managers of SW retail stores are supposed to go and solicit and steal business from competitors ON THE COMPETITORS' STORE PROPERTY. Hanging out trespassing and soliciting and watching for the cops, employees of the stores and security. Classy sales activity!
Indeed, the former good ole boys at SW have definitely turned into SHARKS.

-If you get good people for management, you have a fantastic time.

cons:
-Management is what makes or breaks the store. Management caring or not caring will inevitably spread to the subordinate employees, and proportionally the performance of the store will falter.  While this sounds like a small thing, it can actually significantly change how you approach your work.
-Heavy lifting
-The advancement opportunities seem to be way more reliant on you having a degree in order to fast-track.  Otherwise, you'll be spending multiple years as a part-timer, which for someone who's seeking full-time work, is a massive problem.
-Corporate culture still has a massive stranglehold on a lot of methods for employees to enjoy their work without breaking any rules.

- Great clientele. The friendly customers were usually the best part of my day.
- Friendly coworkers (if you end up at a good location)
-Great product training available, but you have to ask for it.
cons:
- This company will do whatever it can to squeeze the most out of you for the least amount of pay. Need full-time hours? Ok have 39 hours a week so you don’t get paid benefits. Lunch break? How about a 7 hour shift instead so you only get a 10 min break. Every chance they get, they will take advantage of you. If they need product transferred from one store to another, they’ll just get you to drive it so they won’t have to pay a courier, however they will never reimburse your gas. 

- If your store becomes short staffed, don’t expect any help from management. They would rather see you work everyday, open to close, for two months straight than help transfer an existing employee to your store.

I worked at three different stores across two provinces for 2.5 years and while they will “promote” you by giving you more responsibilities, they’ll never increase your wage. Expect minimum wage too. cons: I've been working for two years at sherwin and have never felt like my job was at risk. I love working at Sherwin. However, I've been part-time for 2 years. I've applied from within to try and grab the next step of the ladder for a full-time or assistant manager position with no luck. I'm professional, knowledgeable and competent in my position. I feel like I stand out but Upper management tends to already have a selected person in mind to fill positions posted. The job can get a little repetitive/boring if you work in a smaller store.

pros: Benefits, pay, opportunities for advancement.
cons: Outdated equipment, outdated "old school" company policies that have barely changed over the last 150 years. No vision of the future work environment. Management tends to "black list" people they perceive as a threat to their ego and will sabotage any shot at moving up or out or purposely hold back qualified individuals because they don't want to have to have an opening to fill.

job_title: Sales Associate in New Orleans, LA
pros:
-Friendly, non-competitive atmosphere. 

-Decent pay for a part-time position.

-Not having to clock-out for lunch.

-Working with paint is fun! 

-Getting physically stronger. I don’t have to go to the gym as much.

-Open environment to learn from. You will learn a lot from contractors and your fellow associate and managers. Have a question, just ask anyone.
cons:
-Labor intensive especially when you work the warehouse. Depending on the weather, be prepared to be freezing to death or sweating to death especially when loading and unloading trucks. 

-Steep learning curve for product knowledge and POS system. You will not feel like you are contributing much to the team during your first couple of months.

-Painting contractors can be difficult to work with, at times, because they are unreasonable. For example, another associate pull up the wrong product for the contractor but all he wanted to do was cursed us all out instead of allowing us to fix the issue. But most are fun to work with.

pros: Having a place to work.
cons: Wages, safety issues and work conditions, no a career move

review_title: Have a way of wearing you out. A way of using you up.
pros: The salary is fairly competitive. The stock is performing well, though the profit comes at the price of the sanity of many field personnel.
cons: This company is full of good people; some great people. Hard working folks who genuinely want to do a good job for the company they work for. People that run like hell trying to cover all the bases in the stores they work in and manage, and instead of being rewarded for doing it, they are flogged for failing to toe the line on one of the 74 different metrics that are constantly in play as a layer over an environment where there's a customer coming in or calling an average of every two and half minutes. It makes me wonder if the tasks we expect of our store and field staff, staffed the way we characteristically do (short by our own design and admission) are grounded in reality at all. It seems more likely they are just meant to give something to whip us about.

pros: Having a place to work.
cons: Wages, safety issues and work conditions, no a career move

review_title: Not a good place for Millenials
pros: They have been around for 150 years.
cons: They are operating a company from 150 years ago. This is NOT the place for millennials. If you want to show up at 8:00am, take a lunch break from 12:00pm - 1:00pm, then leave at 5:00pm with absolutely no flexibility, then this is the job for you.

review_title: Upper Management out of touch with reality
pros: Getting to know some of the main customers of the store fairly well.
cons:
Where to start?  Biggest annoyance is how in the Houston District, the appraisal goals for the stores are the same across the board. That means, every store (whether a 10 million or 1 million dollar store) is required to achieve: 50 sales calls per week (more on that later), 100 protexts, 36 new charge accounts, etc. 

Sales calls:  we live in the 21st century, and really and truly these sales calls are outdated and need to not be performance appraisal goals. Also, assistants are told to call from the "Res Repaint" list and to make 25 calls a week. Well if I call 25 customers from that list, I'm going to be calling these people at least 2x a month if not more. As someone who despises sales calls, and usually hangs up on salesmen, I would hate it even more to get called that often.

pros: Good Benefits for all full-time employees, competitive pay, good compensation structure, flexible hours at most positions, many advancement opportunities if your are willing to move and if it isn't an executive/district position.
cons:
Outdated leadership, they are not willing to try new ideas and new things for times that are changing, mid level management only cares for their own agenda and does not really care or invest in their people, extremely numbers driven, too much turn over all over the company top down, no motivating factors beside personal compensation and benefits resulting in lack of teamwork across the whole team.

Working with skeleton crew about 80% of the year, SW has a ton of money but is investing in everything else except the most important Asset which is its people.

pros: Some of the coworkers and customers were friendly, learned a lot, most stores are nice to work at (depends on the coworkers and customers you have)
cons: My coworkers were horrible to deal with. They were always throwing me under the bus, disrespectful, insubordinate and always absent or late. Severely understaffed and constantly busy, overflowing with customers during the summer...which is a horrific combo when you're constantly by yourself and freight decides to show up when you have a long line of customers with complicated problems and high expectations. Expect a retail environment where some customers think they are always right and are not afraid to treat you like trash until they get their way, otherwise they'll throw a big temper tantrum. Customers never really recognize you for your successes, but they will always remember when you occasionally screw up and will make a big deal about it. The list of cons can honestly go on and on, especially if you get placed at the Wilsonville store...as they are always running out of paint and products...stay away!!! Can't warn you enough, not worth the money with all the stress included!

review_title: All work no play or pay
pros:
Good real world experience in running your own business unit. 
Relationships with other management employees.
Develop good customer relationships over the years.
cons:
Long hours and days, sometimes working 6 out of 7 days.
No staff to speak of because hours continue to get cut. Be lucky to find 2 employees in the store at the same time. 
Manager is to wear at least 5 different hats and yet still manage effectively.
Manager responsible for DIY sales even though the marketing is the one to help drive those numbers. Perhaps stand on sidewalk and force them to buy paint.

review_title: Great company, minus some ideas senior management has
job_title: Part Time Sales Associate in Bemidji, MN
pros: My time i have spent with the company has been great, both my manager and assistant manager are awesome, close knit feeling at the store.  I am getting paid quiet well for a part time position in the town, my managers are great about feed back both positive and negative but they don't come down hard on a person the just make sure you know what happened and how you should do it next time or fix it.  plenty of room for advancement, and the stores are generally a lot of fun to work in.
cons: I can't understand some policies that senior management has in place, we are a high quality paint store do we really need to be open on the day after thanksgiving and Christmas REALLY!!!!?  who is going to come buy paint in the middle of winter in northern Minnesota the day after Christmas or thanksgiving.

pros: Great money for a college graduate. Great training. Great product to sell.
cons:
After you receive your first salary, it barely increases from there. For example, you start around $39,000 a year but long term managers make usually at most $60k. I worked in the South East division- very sexist company. They hire women over men only because the company is like 10-20% female, which is barbaric in the 21st century. The men in the company are very sexist and I have no clue how they are still in operation.

As an MTP you will take over the assistant manager duties. The company will not tell you that if you do not move where they assign you then you will be terminated. Even if you have a family or any valid excuse as to why you cannot move 100 miles away to a small town no one has ever heard of, they will take away your big salary, health insurance, everything. 

Overall, this company is for people who are old fashioned and think women are below men. If you just want good money and do not care about company values or rising too high in the management levels of the company then this job is perfect for you!!

pros: They train you hard and you will learn alot about paint products and accessories that you would have never known anywhere else.
cons: Listen to this if you want a honest opinon about what you are about to get yourself into. Managament only cares about one thing, money, they do not care about the employee at all. They do not listen to the MTs concerns but give all the power to the store managers and if they treat you like dirt Sherwin just expects you to dust it off (this is a trial run so if they black list you your just SOL.)  Also be ready to be on your feet for 10 straight hours with no breaks if the store is busy. It is exhausting and than you have to get up and do it all over again at 5am. If you want the truth, find a better company, because they do not care about you at this one. Want the truth, find a better company that cares about you and your growth. This is a sink or swim job and a very, "you better keep quiet about issues," job.

pros: Positive atmosphere, good people.
cons: Work/Life balance not so great.

review_title: Great place to start a career
pros: Great place to learn skills, Great place to advance a career (If you have a 4 year degree, that is), Work environment is generally good. Schedule is really flexible depending on your store, fantastic if you like to move around.
cons: There are not enough employees at larger stores. I am not in management but most of the hours I work are spent alone with no assistance. When it gets busy, customers get angry because they have to wait and leave. Not good business. Pressure from corporate ties the hands of the store management. Corporate is really out of touch with what goes on in the stores.

pros: So working here at Sherwin Williams has taught me so much about the painting world. I love meeting new contractors every week and talking about what they're working on that day. My coworkers are so helpful and nice and just overall a great environment. I was there about 7 months and got promoted to 3rd key holder and also got a small raise. The work is VERY repetitive so it's easy to catch on. I also love helping customers choose colors and different paints that meet their needs. Over all, this is a great company to work for.
cons: Some of the challenges would be that we get short staffed a lot. I'm not most people, but when there's about two people waiting in line and I'm the only one running the store, I feel pressured and some times I end up mistinting or ruining the paint which hurts our store. I also do not like how certain contractors have a set price on a particular product. At my store, the back of the ware house has NO A/C so putting up the delivery truck is a nightmare.

pros: Decent benefits. You'll stay in shape running around and carrying 50lb buckets all day.
cons:
Not enough to staffing
Overworked 
Don't expect lunch breaks 
Underpaid for what they expect of you.
It's not an easy job, expect lots of physcal labor. 
During sales week all managers go out of town and the stores are left short one person. Every year they have these meetings and every year the stores are left even more short handed. Management is aware of the strain it puts on the stores, but nothing changes. 
If management does allow you to hire someone, it's usually only a part-time person. Which takes a significantly longer time to fill than it does a full time person.

review_title: Good company with good benefits if you like the industry but you'll likely burn out
pros: As a manager you make your own schedule, no one watching you all day, when it's slow you can relax and get other things done, you can literally be on your phone all day, don't have to punch out for lunch, can take breaks whenever you want-no set time, good vaca time based on years, Verizon discount 18%, ok health insurance, 6-8 weeks paid maternity time, can win free trip and good bonuses
cons: No sick days, stores usually have at most 4 employees, usually understaffed, district management expect you to work the extra hours when ppl quit, get fired or promoted, can lead to zero work life balance, ppl are constantly calling you when your off as if you get a work phone and you don't, all about numbers, contractors can be rude, they expect the world just because you get bonuses, constantly throwing new things at you, lead generation program, they want store managers to be sales reps and go out and find customers

review_title: Great Pay but at a cost
pros: Great pay for retail, great bonus potential, 401k matching up to 6% (and currently growing like wild fire) pension and getting off around 7 (which for retail is pretty good).
cons: Yes you'll make great money but you'll hardly have any time to spend it.  You will not even have the ability to use your PTO bc they give you the bare minimum to staff your store so when you're down a person, it's hell.  You'll be in a million places at once and hopefully you have a good Asst. Manager but chances are you will not bc they hardly get trained before getting placed, which doesn't seem like a big deal but when they're asked to work on Saturdays (usually alone bc you will not have enough hours to use your part timers during the week and on weekends) it becomes a big deal.

review_title: A great, or awful experience, completely dependant on location.
pros: The job is well rounded, under good management you'll work consistent hours, and if you survive the first month it's a job that can last your entire life. No matter your position, expect to be involved in retail sales, delivery, sales calls, and most importantly, be prepared to learn! The steep learning curve that comes with working at a Sherwin Williams location entirely consists of learning the products themselves. Even with prior retail experience, it'll be at least a month before you feel comfortable tackling a one-on-one interaction with a customer regarding product recommendations. However, if after your first couple months you've decided that you enjoy the paint life, there are ample opportunities for promotion and growth, if you're willing to travel.
cons: What I originally listed as a pro, may also be the biggest con when it comes to Sherwin. No matter your position, expect to be involved in everything. Even as a part time employee, if you prove yourself capable, expect to be a workhorse when times get rough at your location. Throw that work/life balance out the window..

review_title: Overall good, but layely they have really started micro managing.
pros: Great benefits. Job security, their training program. Something new everyday. Never opened past 6. usually get tim off when needed.
cons: Budgets are usually un realistic. they tell you how many hrs your employees can work If you don't get overtime they want you to work as many hours as possible. if you get over time they won't let you. if you are a minority or female you get promoted really fast. Seen someone get promoted that was down in sales. Also seen someone get promoted that was only at position for 1 year. They usually say two years. They have no set requirements for promotions it's who ever they have worked with before or if they were a MTP.. They want you to run a store with the least amount of people as possible. get positive feed back from customers they never say a word. But get 1 bad one and well...

pros:
-Decent pay for out of college
-Benefits were ok
cons:
Where to begin...
-Very unrealistic store expectations. Assistant managers have to make 30 lead generation calls a week while running the store by themselves. Managers have to do weekly "Seal Island" calls where they have to basically stalk potential customers in Home Depot and Lowe's Parking lots...really??
-The stores are open 7 days a week and only closed 4 days during the year, so expect to work holidays and weekends (including 4th of July, Memorial Day, Christmas Eve, Labor Day, & New Year's Eve). Very bad work/life balance.
-Understaffed stores, it's typical to work 12 hour shifts by yourself. Part-time hours have been drastically reduced so there is not as much part-time help available. This leaves Managers and Assistant Managers working by themselves most of the time.
-44 hour work week rather than a typical 40 hour workweek, those extra hours really do add up!
-Heavy lifting that can consist of 100+ pounds 
-It can take awhile to advance with the company and you have to be willing to move around

I suggest college graduates to do research before taking an offer as an MTP with this company. You can find something so much better!

pros:
-Sometimes you get to work with decent individuals and the contractor relationships you build are typically fun and endearing.

-In-store Keurig
-Nice discount on paint
-Hard to get fired
cons:
-High turnover rate all around. I had 6 managers in the 3 years I was with the company.
-They do not care about the safety of their racks of paint on the wall. While in my position, an entire wall fell out due to too heavy paint/racks and not installed correctly. The first thing upper management said when they were contacted was, "How did this happen." Most empathetic humans would say, "Is everyone alright, did anyone get hurt?"
-Not entirely upfront with the amount of heavy lifting that is required. said 50+, urethanes and road-paint etc. are definitely heavier.
-District Management should at least pretend to care more about the stores they're in charge of.
-Update POS, pretty much as old as the Internet, multi-million dollar company and can't get new software that would help with store efficiency.

job_title: Assistant Store Manager in West Palm Beach, FL
pros: Fairly good health benefits and the Stock Purchase Plan (401K) is performing amazingly. Also, the credit union gives low-interest loans and offers low-interest credit cards.
cons: The new management in the Southeastern area is either completely out of touch with the needs of the employees or they just don't care. We suspect the latter is true, given that nothing has  changes since the "secret meeting" with HR from Cleveland a few months ago. The implementation of "Seal Island" now changed to "Sales Call Wednesdays" has brought manager morale to an all-time low. This extremely unethical strategy of "poaching" customers from the parking lots of our competitors along with the forced sales calls that all managers and assistant managers have to make and document have made running the store efficiently nearly impossible. To add insult to injury, any employee who doesn't comply with the plethora of new rules, regulations, and mandated tasks can be written up on the spot and this is being used by management as leverage to intimidate employees through fear of losing their jobs. This is a pitiful work environment that is unhealthy to everyone!

job_title: Assistant Manager in Cedar Rapids, IA
pros: Some of your cow workers are cool
cons: Physically, mentally, and emotionally draining. Constant pressure to control the uncontrollable. No work life balance.

review_title: Great place for a career, but MTP program needs to be re-evaluated
job_title: Third Key, Sales Associate in Tacoma, WA
pros: Great Place to plan out a great career! We are like one big family in the seattle district, we would all go great lengths for one another! There is great pay great benefits, even in these hard economic times.
cons: It can be very difficicult to be promoted when you are having to go against the MTPS. We don't really think its very fair for the rest of us in the company that have worked so hard and for so long just to be ignored. The MTP program should really be re-evaluated, a longer training period for one example, and you shouldn't have to have a certain college degree just to be eligable for the program. We keep hiring MTP's when there are so many that deserve to be promoted and can't because there are to many MTP's in the company.

pros: The ability to run a store pretty much the way you want. Quarterly and yearly bonus if you qualify.
cons: No pays raise and a '4' review if you did not hit your sales number for the year. Being on 6 month goals because of the 4 review.  in April all managers and sales reps were giving an overall '4' rating even if all other aspect of their job was a '3' or better. In the past years this one metric never warranted such a bad review. We should have been told long ago that we were to be graded differently and  that we were to be graded on just one aspect  instead of the whole picture.

review_title: Sherwin-Williams: Where Hard Work Really Does Pay Off
pros: Working for Sherwin-Williams is like running your own company with someone else's money. You are given the trust and resources to make the decisions necessary to be successful. It takes an entrepreneurial spirit but the rewards are plentiful. Promotion from within is over 90%. It doesn't matter where you came from or who you know, what matters is hard work and performance. That's truly what gets you ahead here. Also, the benefits at SW are great: 401k, pension, medical, dental, vision, plus quarterly and annual bonuses. Performance pays.
cons: Being spread out in retails stores does not always provide the comradery one might get in an office setting. You still get know people around you but there are rarely social events or after-work drinks. Additionally, working in our stores is quite physical. It's not a desk job, which is great, but it requires heavy lifting at times and constant movement. It's not a job for complacent or lazy people.

review_title: Hard work, Good company, but watch yourself
job_title: Sales Representative in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Get real world experience.  On the sales side of the business, you get a lot of customer contact.  If you work in the store, you learn what it takes to run a business with the support of a company behind you.  You have a lot of opportunity to move around the company
cons: The hours in the stores can be long. Most stores are open 7 days a week.  Sometimes you are subject to working 7 days a week and this type of work can take weeks to change,  Upper management sometimes seems very disintrested in your situation because "thats is what they went though" type attitude.  You will see a culture that is strong, but the senior management demostrates many times that they do not care about the people under them, just the only the numbers.

review_title: Company has gone down the drain
pros: Fun work, can have awesome boss, goal oriented, and good stepping stone. Benefits are great if you stay with the company for at least 3 years.
cons: Middle Management only cares about there bonuses. Company only cares about signing up customers for accounts. We are constantly understaffed and have a high turnover in the stores. I have an awesome manager, but there are so many better opportunites out there right now. We are also underpaid for our job. Every other paint store pays their employees at least $2 more and gives part timers a bonus.  Benefits are better at Sherwin, but most part timers don't become vested in their 401k.

pros: Located all over the U.S. There is opportunity for advancement and they spend quite a bit of money on training and development.
cons: The company doesn't invest any money into their IT systems which makes the daily grind very aggravating. The corporate culture and constant bombardment of company initiatives becomes overwhelming. Upper management 's expectations can be unreal at times and they are never pleased. You could be hitting your sales goals every month and they will still tell you that your under performing. The way this company does business sets you up for hard times since 1 out of 3 customers that comes into the store is angry about something that it completely out of your control. Worst part is that the company limits how many people you can hire so you are constantly understaffed and overworked. They do not pay nearly enough considering how hard we work and how much money we make the company.

pros: Continuously on the move managing a wide range of things. It was great to interact with customers daily while building relationships. Advancement can be quick if you are the "type" they are looking for.
cons: Emails about marketing excellence and keeping up on your employees performances. Easily replaceable since they acquired a multi-billion dollar company (Valspar) and they need to hire new college grads to replace tenure employees to offset the cost. Don't ask for a full time employee- nothing but babysitting your part time help. I didn't mind working retail hours but most do. Upper Management promotes people they like rather than proven employees. I had the second most profitable store in a large district and yet loss prevention came in to falsely accusing me of something I did not do. I have heard testimonies of large companies doing this to employees who need to be replaced with cheaper labor but in reality I experienced the same situation and found afterwards that others were removed as well. Large companies financially critique the payroll in the wrong measures after reaping the costs of mergers & acquisitions.

review_title: Great place to work, learn, grow...
pros: Get a lot of experience within the industry regardless of job function, learn a lot from superiors and co-workers, most jobs use a significant amount of computer technology which is transferrable to other jobs (internal and external). Performance review is great. HQ is really nice place to work
cons: A little stuffy and old feeling at times. Many life-time workers @ SW (25+ years). Takes longer to move up when you start out fresh because of office politics, "everyone has their place" (This is not an idea held by all management and is usually the opinion of someone not supervising you anyway -- ie: People who have been in entry-level jobs for 15+ years).

pros: Sherwin-Williams will offer a better than average package to new employees.  It is definitely a hands on type of job for individuals who prefer to get a little dirty.  This is not for someone that is opposed to physical labor.
cons: The opportunities for advancement are definitely there...If you want to move every year from city to city and generally only continue to take Store management positions.  Store managers work very long hours and the incentive to be a store manager is based primarily on status and bonuses.  The salary difference between a store manager and assistant manager is very minimal when you add the extra hours and the added pressure of being the store manager.

review_title: Comex Group does not understand corp culture and how to sales paint in the US.
pros: I hate to say it but its better than not having a job.  There are still devoted people (good people) that are still working there but  if they had other options they would be gone in a heart beat.
cons:
Too many VP's without paint knowledge nor a grasp on what it takes to sale paint.  Sales VP's and AM's talk a good game but have no customer base and can't bring in sales so they are dependent on the Field Reps.

Store service is good but it was the best overall in the industry but now Corp is cutting but people and hours, inventory, etc. and makes it hard for stores to supply customer needs.

job_title: Outside Sales Representative in New Haven, CT
pros: A lot of room for advancement, especially if you are starting from a part time or assistant manager position.  A place you can definitely make a life long career out of.
cons: Typical corporation.  High stress environment.  Very top heavy corporate structure, edicts in the field being passed down to the field from people who haven't worked in the trenches for over 10 years.  Somewhat unrealistic budgets and goals, but they will work with you if you are putting in the effort.

pros: They have good benefits.  If you need a paycheck you will get it on time.
cons:
You have to deal with dirt bags all day every day.  They will complain about anything because they know the game. District management is full of douche bags who will throw loyal employees under the bus rather than do the right thing and stand up to bogus complaints from "painters". You know the type, an out of work meth head with maybe 3 teeth. Don't laugh   
all you managers know it's true. 
Besides this, stores are understaffed. Managers are supposed to work ungodly hours to make things work. 
If you want your livelihood dependent on dishonest contractors, "painters" etc, then sherwin williams is for you.

review_title: 17 year employee, good times and bad. Company has lost track of what made it .
job_title: Store Manager in New York, NY
pros: Great benefits, opportunity for advancement if willing to move.
cons: The this year vs. last year philosophy is not a way to build a long term business. Only concerned now about stock price and sacrificing its American stores in the process. Investing all money in foreign ventures.

review_title: Part time job in high school and through college
pros: Was lucky enough to work with a great group of people. Never work nights, they're not open that late. Once I moved up within the store I experienced more freedom and say in things (as well as added responsibility).
cons: It's retail. But extremely specialized knowledge is needed. Takes a long time to feel comfortable. At a more industrial focused location it can be a quite physically exhausting job. Though you don't work nights, tend to work rather long shifts, much of which might be alone or only with one other person. If it's busy, there are no breaks, no lunch. Just have to eat when you can. Winter months can be the opposite, can go hours without seeing anyone and have really nothing to do (which can be good or bad depending on your view). Have to work ~10 hour weekend days regularly. Cold calls.

review_title: Not the worst, not the best either
pros: You get to do a lot of different things: from hiring, managing expenses, training staff, meeting with customers, handling complaints, etc. Each day will be different.
cons:
Company is always looking to save money. Read: you will be working with barely enough staff. Many stores only have 5 staff members, and most of them are part-time -- yet the stores are open everyday for long hours. This translates to you, the manager, working many long shifts and at least one person working an entire day alone. When an employee quits, upper management is in no rush to replace the position, I'm fact it is common practice for upper management to stretch it out for months before replacing an employee, assistant manager, or manager so that the money can be saved.
They sell you on this "you can work anywhere you want" idea when you're hired. In reality, you can only go where THEY want you to work. Upper management doesn't care about any of this, we're all just pawns for their 5 and 6 figure bonus checks.

pros:
Decent entry-level salary with bonus opportunity. You start somewhere around 45-46k and get a 1k bump at 6 and 18 months of service, in addition to 1yr percent bonus. 

Opportunity to advance fairly quickly, especially if you are willing to relocate.

Stores close earlier than most places because contractors are busier in the mornings.
cons:
Most stores understaffed, which makes it harder to focus on goals. Instead of giving stores an extra full time staff member they give you two part timers so they don’t have to pay benefits. Part timers can not open or close store until they have been there for 3 months, so manager or assistant must be there at all times. Can be highly stressful if shorthanded and busy. 

They make assistant managers work 44 hours a week, managers have to work 48.

Conservative company with old fashioned dress code and appearance policy (make you hide tattoos) 

Their insurance is through Aetna and isn’t great

No breaks for lunch

review_title: The best company I have ever worked for in terms of company culture, employee compensation, and quality of products.
pros: There's plenty of opportunity to grow professionally within this company if you are a hard worker. As a manager and assistant you can earn bonuses if you hit your store sales. High quality products make it easier to sell. Management truly cares about your success and wants you to have a work/life balance not just all hours dedicated to work. Flexible hours. Retirement plans good as well.
cons: If you are a woman seeking employment here you need to have tough skin to deal with some of the contractors that come in and are not all exactly proper business men. Better also have no qualms about lifting some heavy equipment either! Products can get pretty heavy. There are dolly's to help but still require some muscle and tough skin.

job_title: Decorative Product Specialist in Mount Prospect, IL
pros: Sherwin-Williams stores is a friendly place to work.  It's not difficult and there's not much stress.
cons: No training, management in store truly are not interested in team effort with DPS.  There is nothing on the store's computer to find answers for products, training, etc.  Although we definitely bring sales into the store, there is no bonus, no raise within the year and no incentive.  I love the job, but it really doesn't have a career path....no benefits, no full-time available and no support in the position.

review_title: Pride in our paints and our people - Sherwin Williams.
job_title: Assistant Store Manager in Cincinnati, OH
pros:
History making company that has been around for over 100 years (Founded 1866) 
A lot of autonomy in your work if you are a manager/assistant manager. You know your roles and responsibilities and have ability to choose how you follow them out.
Very competitive salary, bonus opportunities based on performance, health benefits, stock options, pension, etc. 
A company with huge brand recognition in its market.
Ability to work with entreprenurs and build relationships.
ability to learn a very unique skill set and knowledge about painting and home renovations.
cons:
Clients are very impatient and sometimes just bad people. 
Some expectations are unreachable which can bring down motivation.
The market decides your bonus and really it can be an unstable market at times. 
You get paint all over you!

review_title: You're going to work your @ss off
pros: Great benefits, good bonus structure, you don't need to know anything to start with the company, great starting job for college graduates, overtime (unless you're salaried), 401k match
cons: Long hours, no work/life balance, no real compensation for managers if they exceed their hours, huge push during slow seasons, and lead generation. There seems to be an ongoing retention issue and hiring part time help is like pulling teeth. All the stores seem to be understaffed - typically having a staff of four (manager, assistant, two part timers) for a 1.5m store. Assistants typically work 44hrs a week and Managers are 48, but they are expected to work more. There's limited help from upper management. There have been whole months I've worked 52 - 60hrs a week, no overtime, and upper management never followed up with help despite multiple discussions. Possibly the boss I had at the moment but it seemed they were hoping they could hold off until the situation resolved itself while I burned out.

review_title: Great learning experience but more con's than pros
pros: They people I work with are great and we all get along so well. I've learned a lot and continue to do so.
cons: I get handed most of the work because of my knowledge of all the products and can match stains and colors to a t but yet they don't want to pay me any thing more or make me full time. Not a Good place to grow and move up unless you plan on being there for the rest of your life to wait for the opportunity. The company is greedy and to controlling. They expect way to much of their employees for little reward

pros: Good benefits-401k, insurance, okay place to start your career but unless you are willing to move all over you cannot advance
cons: Incredibly discriminatory towards females.  Preach a lot about diversity and gender inclusion however either tries to meet quotas to hit diversity requirement and consistently puts females in "token" positions or uses them as a commodity rather than individuals with talent.  Still very much the good ole boys club.  Have also seen terrible decisions by management.  The company continues to put profit and stock price ahead of people, until they figure out that people are the biggest asset this company has they will have incredibly high attrition, turnover, and will be just like the rest of corporate america that treats women and minorities with no respect. Women are underpaid as with the rest of America.  Work life balance from manager training program on up is terrible. What corporate speaks about to what is actually executed by leadership in the field does not match. Has potential to have a great culture if there were managers who cared more about people than the bonus they make.  What Cleveland corporate training teaches vs what district management and VP of sales actually carry out do not match at all.

review_title: Basically, happy to be working here.
pros: Driver's wages are higher here than elsewhere. Able to be home weekly, if not twice a week. New equipment is repaired and maintained on a timely basis. Able to actually plan for retirement. Pay is direct deposit and NEVER a bounced check! The trucking industry is full of slow to pay and low paying companies. This is not a trucking company. It is a paint company that has it's own trucks.
cons: Bureaucracy tends to slow progress in the company. Problems show up and can take 9-12 months to be addressed. During the busy, summer season your weekend can be as little as 34 hours off. (I would rather be busy than not in this economy.) Most of my concerns I can live with and do not interfere with my day to day job functions. I do not recommend this job to anyone without explaining EXACTLY what is involved.

pros:
As a part timer for 2 1/2 plus years, I greatly enjoyed my time here. It's wonderful for a part time college job that doesn't pay minimum wage. The company cares about you as a part timer and training you right. If you are interested after you graduate (if you are a college student) the MTP program is a wonderful and logical next step.

Paid time off (I got 40 paid hours a year as a part timer, which is awesome)
401K benefits (Again as a part timer, which is awesome!)
Flexible schedule since there aren't to many people at one store. The manager or assistant manager makes the schedule themselves, not some computer program like larger retail locations.
cons: Upper management (above the district level) is somewhat disconnected from the behavior of contractors. Part timers (at least where I work) were told to start doing 5 calls to contractor a week. Many contractors don't care to get calls, let alone from part timers that they mostly view as order takers (unless you've been there for a couple of years like myself and earned their respect).

review_title: Strong company that needs to look out for it's employees.
pros: Stable Company, Sense of Community, Easy  to build relationships with customers and other employees, Fair pay, 401(k) options, Easy to transfer to new locations (I did twice), challenging, easy to make into career. This can be a fun job and it can be a very stressful job during the busy season.
cons: Contractors can have very high expectations (to be fair we claim to be the pro's) and if your experience in paint goes no further than Sherwin-Williams you will get frustrated customers. Sales training is good, product and paint knowledge takes years to feel comfortable with. If your a clutz like myself you will spend a lot of money on your uniform! I have worked for the company 2 years and have not recieved a full-time position; even though they have just hired 2 new part-timers and I consistently have to ask for more hours. Has a very 'corporate' presence.

review_title: Decent pay but doesn't care about employees.
pros: The pay is decent. They focus on customer service.  If you don't mind moving you can advance. They offer bonuses for managers and assistant managers.
cons: They don't care about you or your family.  They really don't care about injured employees.  They only care when you are making them money.  Most managers are exempt from overtime and can work 50 to 70 hours a week.  I know from personal experience with an on the job injury that they do everything possible to not pay for care. They have a third party administration dealing with injured workers and they will delay and deny care and treatment even required surgery recommended by a doctor.  It's pretty sorry when an employee works for them for 15 + years to end up getting treated like s#!t.  They own many other paint brands and and most of the time you are competing against your own company for sales.

review_title: Work was enjoyable, Corporate was not
pros: Really enjoyed the job, helping people complete projects and dream up their new home color schemes, matching colors was incredibly interesting. Benefits for fulltime employees.
cons:
Corporate hired only outside for management training program. Promised a chance and management since I had a college degree but since I started part time they're was no place to move up. Felt like their was no incentive for hard work, for a long time I made sure I did a really good job and reducing costs and mistints and upselling customers to increase lines per transaction. But never felt like this was recognized or even mattered.  
Possibly not all stores despose of hazardous waste in a proper way.
Raise for three years with company did not reflect my performance.

review_title: I felt ill-trained to handle all facets of my job, although I was well-compensated and worked very hard for the company.
pros: The company has many friendly, caring people working in key areas.  They pay management well; with bonus opportunities and compensations.  They are very customer-focused, although they take the phrase "the customer is always right" to the extreme--with sometimes severe consequences to local management.
cons: Don't buck the system; even if you are right, you will be punished for it.  The company does not treat different locations fairly and distinctly.  If the guy in the next city is doing well, you should be doing well also, regardless of differences in local markets.  They are fixated more on profits than on doing the right thing, although I believe this is a sore point with many corporations these days.

job_title: Sales and Service Specialist in Bend, OR
pros: Have been very flexible with my schedual, manager is great, good benifits and retirement planning with company match. Regular raises
cons: outside management is totally disconected from the store and give off the impression that they do not care about employees at the store level at all. They have quite a few bonus benifits listed for employees on their website, such as employee referals and paying for you to get a rosseta stone program but if you request it they will just ignore it if you are not persistant in calling them about the status, will still take months to get it taken care of.

pros:
Was nice to get a job right out of college making 40k.

Surrounded by good people in my store

never clocked out for lunch
cons:
Long hours

hurts your back

dumb painters

upper management is clueless and has no idea what is going on in store , only care about numbers

also your boss  and your boss's boss they get moved around so much. building strong relationships with them is pointless which sucks because they are in charge of your promotions but they just leave in a year or 2 so your handwork that gets noticed goes away because there is a new guy to take their place . which makes moving up really hard because the reset button gets pressed and promises are unkept. that is why i left. they jerk you around to much

want to transfer ???? fat chance in hell, you are  number not a person

review_title: Gone down hill over the last couple years
pros: Benefits. 401k. Health insurance. Pension.
cons:
Understaffed constantly. Part timers are always leaving for higher pay or for full time. Lots of responsibility and lots of the blame fall on lower level managers when it’s corporate who handles some of the larger deals and contracts. Margin and profit are completely out of the stores control. Which results in terrible p&l and getting emails telling you to do more, even though you had no control over the discount structure. 
Bonus would be good, if we ever got it. It hasn’t always been like this, which is disheartening because up until a year and a half ago I really enjoyed my job.  They try to make it out like you control your store, but it has become so micromanaged over the last year or so, that managers have hardly any say anymore. It’s like they are setting us up to fail.

pros: The company offers an excellent ability to relocate. In general the store staff is usually likeable. You will get to meet the VPs and maybe President of the company in your time here. You will also get great experience running a retail store because you will be thrown into the fire and will have to hope the store staff is knowledgeable enough to aid you.
cons: You are not as important as the stock price. Your family isn't as important as the stock price. My old district has had major turnover due to people quitting. This is due to unfavorable hiring choices made after the loss of a district leader. They hire college grads with no experience instead of promoting full-time employees with years of experience. This is a complex industry with many variables and it cannot be learned in the 2 months of management training. This is a company wide practice. Drink the Kool-Aid or else don't bother applying.

review_title: Infidelity Between Company Subordinate and Technical Reps
pros: In the Beginning of the hiring process they provide alot of information on benefits and working your way up the ladder.  Health Benefits and retirement
cons: The Pacific Northwest-Northern Idaho-Montana Employees have document able gross misconduct. There have been several cases of the regional manager covering up infidelities between married employees, often times ending in divorce and then promotion for the employee that has the subordinate job. There is a serious problem in this region, The company cell phones have been used to communicate in sexual manners through text messages-calls at odd hours and extreme lengths of call times, there are also video and personal photos being shared. All of this data is stored and can be subpoenaed and employees can be sued in civil court and must testify under oath. The rampant infidelity is documented and easily accessed.

pros: Good pay and good benefits. The company likes to promote from within.
cons:
As someone previously mentioned, psychological & emotional bullying/mobbing are alive and well within this company.

I have seen employees targeted for removal by management (after voicing concerns, or making a mistake on the job). These employees are treated/labeled as 'problem employees', and conditions are made so difficult for the employees over time (through subtle, difficult-to-prove forms of mistreatment) that they either quit, or are terminated after the performance evaluation system has been used against them.

If the employee leaves, the aggressors act surprised. As a co-worker, witnessing this counterproductive behavior permeates a culture of fear and silence (if you say something, you could be the next target).

review_title: Took A While But LOVE IT Now
pros: Went into the acquisition hesitant.  The first year full of learning new systems and processes we did a lot of WTH and SMH.  Still do that on occasion BUT did that at Valspar too.  I have been pleasantly surprised and thrilled that the company is not the cut throat Valspar we knew the last few years. They listen and make change when they can and provide you the tools you need to get your job done (NOT used to that).  Employees are still important at SHW.  They actually provide training when you become a manager (yes, training is needed).
cons: Processes could be improved - sometimes feels like there are people who push buttons in CLE (if it's not red, I cannot do that.  If it's blue, I can).  Hear "that's the way we've always done it." too often.  It's 2018, we shouldn't have to call someone to get something done!

job_title: Sales Associate/Key Holder in Russellville, AR
pros: Good for college students, decent pay for part time work, always busy, great stepping done job
cons: Customers are sometimes some of the meanest spiteful people, which Sherwin bends over backwards, disregarding warranties to please. Often, bad precedence is set by managers and it falls to the assistant and part timers to clean up. Little evaluation of managers actual capabilities to operate the store and manage personell efficiently.

pros: Not many companies today have both a pension and a six percent matching 401K.  This is a very big plus for any company.
cons: Upper management is very ego centric.  When the district succeeds it is because of what they did not because of the hard work done in the “trenches”.  They have also forgotten what it is like to be in stores.  They now have store management making outside sales calls.  This new task did not come with any increased support in the stores, no increased part time hours nor increased full time employee support.  This has increased the already high number of hours worked 48 (required) to on average 52-54.  Work life balance has pretty much disappeared all together.

job_title: Lab Technician III in Chicago, IL
pros:
Good Retirement Package
401K and Pension
cons:
Not rewarded for hard work or knowledge. If you don't network with the right people, you aren't getting promoting or decent raises. People who fail and cost the company money fail upward to better positions, rather than lose their job or responsibility. Zero to no opportunities for advancement outside of Cleveland. If you don't agree with with the ideas of management your going nowhere. Grade school mentality when people are identified for promotions, If your popular with the managers you can go far even if more qualified, educated, and knowledgeable people are competting for the same jobs or promotions. Chemistry courses are required in the technical labs for jobs that won't need that type of education, while no management courses or experience are required for management positions. Some older chemist and scientist only have high school educations, while newer people are required to have at least 16 credit hours of college chemistry.
 Communincations are exteremely poor throughout the company. Salaries of Grade levels are kept Top Secret!
Extremely poor medical benefites. (Aetna medical insurance is terrible!!!)

pros: The management training program was excellent, although quite short. Great support from management and upward momentum to excel (assuming you went through the MIT program).
cons:
Typical corporate things such as a push to have all part-time employees and work them odd hours - such as opening, leaving, and coming back to close.

Not a very safe environment with all of the toxic chemicals that you are in constant contact with although there is no real way to change this. 

If you were an MIT, most of the staff had a severe dislike for you as you can jump up to be a store manager within 6 months, surpassing senior employees.

The tuition reimbursement was nonexistent. You could apply for it, however, it is never approved.

Unfortunate decisions for management to keep top-tier employees in their district and will not help you move if you need/desire to.

review_title: At least I'm still working: for now
pros: Very, very, very safety conscious. Willing to spend money on certain equipment upgrades.  Interesting style of training.
cons: Lack of common sense.  Claim to be willing to spend money to improve or maintain the machinery, but deny most expense requests for replacement parts. High management turnover.  Have trouble telling the truth to unionized employees.  Seem to always be looking for ways to reduce wage expenditures, without overtly trying to break the union.  Keep local management in the dark about future plans.  Have lied at least twice since corporate take-over 3 years ago.  First about reducing the work force, and second about laying off union employees.  Seem to think we are just group of under educated half-wits that need to be lead by the hand and shown how to do things  "THE GREAT AMERICAN WAY!!!!!"  Ugh.  Our future here is very uncertain.  100 plus years of Canadian business down the drain.

job_title: Regional Financial Analyst in Buford, GA
pros: Decent benefits but overworked employees.
cons: This company used to be great to work for however, Management has become extremely greedy ever since acquisition of Valspar. The Management has started placing managers in roles they are not qualified or understand the business and do not wish to understand business. Unqualified managers belittle, and bully those who do not get the result they want without understanding complexity of the problems. Initial feedback from managers is to turn a blind eye, belittle employees, attack their intelligence and emotional wellbeing. While this round of bullying has been occurring, encouraged by upper management, there is also no appreciation for amount of work employees do while constantly being short staffed and constant increase of workload. I had one manager tell me that I should be working more than 40 hours a week and should not have a personal life. Same boss has also explained that while on vacation, I should log in and get several hours of work completed. This according to him is considered a “benefit.” Lastly, it is not safe to discuss your opinions in this company as you will be brought down incessantly, until you leave the company. The culture has significantly gotten worse over the years and more specifically with acquisition of Valspar.

review_title: Great company, but people don't quit jobs - they quit managers.
pros: The company as a whole is very cooperative with the schedules and needs of their employees. They offer great benefits (even to part-timers), and I've never heard any of their managers say a bad thing about the way the company treats them or does business. They also provide you with your own Sherwin Williams work clothing.
cons:
If I knew then what I know now about employment law, then the manager I had at this location would have been in serious trouble. I've known other store managers for the company and they were absolutely fantastic, but it was unfortunate that the one was so unkind and without class. 

Poor training -- you essentially train yourself through personal observation. I hear it's better if you're part of the sales management program.

job_title: Part Time Sales Associate in Rockville, MD
pros: Sherwin-Williams, provided you show initiative, is willing to move you up fairly quickly. Currently I'm a PT, but after less than a year with the company I am going to FT, and will begin receiving benefits. Our management can be fun yet understanding of how to incentivize us to do better, and almost, dare I say it, friends. While the work can be a bit much, and customers always seem to want to walk in during a lunch-break, in a sense it's rewarding.
cons: At times, unfortunately, there is a disconnect between the general staff and management. With no appropriate vehicle to express discontent, outside of going to HR (which is a bit annoying considering every "issue" doesn't need to be handled by HR), it leaves the general staff frustrated that we cannot speak to our managers. The company can be sort of cheap at times, and don't realize it bites them in the butt do so.

pros: As a part timer and someone in school, the manager was very lenient and allowed me to make my schedule around school. The supervisor, because Sherwin-Williams won't make him a manager after 15 years, is a great man that has set up a system that is easy to follow and if done correctly, will allow the mechanic to constantly fix machines with no interaction or asking help for others.
cons: This place has 2 full-time and a 1 part-timer position. It would be beneficial to make this a 3 full-time job place, since you are constantly being pulled away from the machinery in order to help customers who come in to the store to drop off machinery to be repair, buy stuff from the store, and set up payment plans that take a lot of time away from repairing.

pros: Good reputation as a company. Stability over a number of years. Benefits are okay. Strong stock performance. Flexibility on an hour to hour basis.
cons: Your good performance is a two edged sword. The other edge cuts your throat the following year when inevitable business cycles occur. Retail hours are getting longer and longer with a view to service business that probably won't buy from us anyway. Combination of longer hours and short staffing is creating a situation where we are physically unable to provide the very kind of service we claim to have.

pros: The benefits if you can make it to full-time are amazing, the job is laid back, the customers are generally awesome because they are coming to you expecting expert advice that they can't get at big box stores so they understand when you explain things and are appreciative. Co-workers typically share the same attitude as you when it comes to the store, corporate is a pain to deal with sometimes, but that's with any company.
cons: Occasionally you get a store manager, and sometimes a city/district manager that stay true to their clique and if you aren't from the area or are a transfer then good luck getting them to take your side on anything. Most managers care about every customer, and even if they don't they pretend to, but sometimes (and this is why I left the company) you get a manager who is rude, condescending, and just plain mean to some customers. Just couldn't take it anymore.

pros: Good reputation as a company. Stability over a number of years. Benefits are okay. Strong stock performance. Flexibility on an hour to hour basis.
cons: Your good performance is a two edged sword. The other edge cuts your throat the following year when inevitable business cycles occur. Retail hours are getting longer and longer with a view to service business that probably won't buy from us anyway. Combination of longer hours and short staffing is creating a situation where we are physically unable to provide the very kind of service we claim to have.

pros: The benefits if you can make it to full-time are amazing, the job is laid back, the customers are generally awesome because they are coming to you expecting expert advice that they can't get at big box stores so they understand when you explain things and are appreciative. Co-workers typically share the same attitude as you when it comes to the store, corporate is a pain to deal with sometimes, but that's with any company.
cons: Occasionally you get a store manager, and sometimes a city/district manager that stay true to their clique and if you aren't from the area or are a transfer then good luck getting them to take your side on anything. Most managers care about every customer, and even if they don't they pretend to, but sometimes (and this is why I left the company) you get a manager who is rude, condescending, and just plain mean to some customers. Just couldn't take it anymore.

pros:
Tolerable for a short period of time as it gets your foot in the door with only a degree and no management experience, IF you want to move up within the company. The company wants you to follow this specific career path or makes work miserable until you leave: Asst Manager>Store Manager>Sales Rep>Sales Manager, etc.
Lots of company specific training for this position but if you move up there is a real lack of support to learn new roles.
Competitive benefits.
cons:
Management only sees you as a body. Your experience with Sherwin-Williams will vary greatly depending on the manager(s) you report to. Mine were awful and very unprofessional at times.
Retail hours (open 7 days/wk)...often worked LONG shifts by myself with NO breaks. 
Worked in ~10 locations in CNY and nearly all are understaffed and management doesn't care, just asks more of you. 
Nearly impossible to take a sick day. With such a small staff at each branch, if you were to call in it means someone else has to agree to take on your shift if they're even available. 
Poor work/life balance.

pros: Great benefits. Easy to promote. Multiple training opportunities.
cons: Long work weeks, especially as a manager. 48 minimum - upper management expects around 60 hours a weeks. Difficult to find support from outside the store. It is difficult to meet expectations of upper management on a consistent basis. Be prepared to do the same job as part time help with little time do your actual job.

review_title: too much work for sales associate and third key holder and not enough compensation.
pros: great hours for a student. they work around one's school schedule very well. i had and still have a great relationship with my assistant manager and manager. That may be a result of the people and not necessarily anything to do with Sherwin-Williams.
cons: they work you every single weekend. over a five year span, i worked on average 49-50 weekends a year. management always complains and whines when you take time off. dealing with paint contractors on a daily basis is banality at its absolute worst. no offense, actually a little, paint contractors are not the brightest or deepest individuals you'll meet. they always act like it's a sin to ask them for payment. i was under the impression that sherwin williams was a business. one important thing to note, gossip and rumors spread real quick. be careful of what you say and how you say it to other employees.

review_title: Training Practically Nonexistent. Higher Demand, Fewer Employees. Not prepared to take on JIT Demands of their customers
pros: Good benefits/opportunities if you can stay with the company for a long time in office/sales/management roles.
cons:
Little to no training available - mostly learn by "sink or swim" method.
Majority of locations across most of their divisions are painfully understaffed.
Upper Management focuses more on buying out their competition than on improving their own stores/facilities.
Little emphasis on diversity or modernizing their business structure.
HR looks out for the Good Ol' Boys with "traditional" values.

review_title: Being a Store Manager is not about managing a store-it's about being a Sales Representative.
pros: Great benefits, lots of vacation time, if you get lucky you'll get cash bonuses. Employee discount is helpful if you own a home and can do DIY projects.
cons: Immense pressure to increase sales dollars. If you don't increase sales enough, your District Manager will threaten you with demotion or termination. They lure you in with promises of doubling your salary in bonuses, then work you 60 to 70 hours a week in the summer with no cash bonus in sight unless you can grow sales. If you want to be a Sales Representative, being a Store Manager is the in-between step. But if you want a job in retail management, stay away from Sherwin.

pros: You get to make a lot of friends that you'll see on a day-to-day basis. You meet people of all different cultures. Becoming familiar with all of the products and processes gives you more confidence when helping customers, especially contractors. There's always something to do, learn or clean so you'll never have a dragging day. My boss is absolutely amazing
cons: Pay is no where near close to the amount of work done. You're only given 15 minutes for lunch. Temperature in store is controlled by out-of-state entity who/that has no conception of weather. Corporate continuously pushes employees to sell products that either don't work, are irrelevant to customer needs or just don't make sense. Corporate constantly gives customers whatever they ask for if a complaint is made (95% their fault for lack of knowledge) and never ask us what really happened. Only tell us to improve. They constantly promise you with growth opportunities, but no one actually receives them.

review_title: Lost focus on what made the company great
pros:
Good Pay 
Excellent Incentive plan for management
Upward Mobility
cons: Where to begin. Since the change in leadership at the top the culture has transformed to one of do more with less tools and profits above ALL ELSE. Also focus has shifted to Lowes being the priority so we are left at the store level with no product to sell for months now and trucks that don't arrive on time.  Then have to deliver news of a price increase to customers that we have been servicing poorly because of this. Upper management acts as if it business as usual pushing new initiatives weekly.

pros: Great benefits for retail management, health, dental vision, 401k, pension, tuition assistance. Other good things depend on your training store. My manager is flexible with off time, and scheduling so long as I get in 40-44 hours a week. The job is rather easy, if you don't know something, someone who works there probably does, so you pick things up by watching and listening. It helps to be flexible in with a very diverse customer base.
cons:
Some contractors are a little impatient but they are out the door quick. There is some heavy lifting and you are on your feet. I was a bit snooty knowing I was doing this when other college grads I knew were in cozy cubicles surfing ESPN, but I'm getting paid the same if not more. Some stores probably don't have good managers and you'll be working where they want you once it's time for you to be an assistant manager, but that's expected. 
It's retail... but it's better than most other retail gigs... hours, sundays closes most places. etc

job_title: Management Training Program (MTP) in New York, NY
pros: This is a great job out of college, but also has the potential to be long term career move. Many people stick around in this company for a long time because there are so many benefits to staying. Career growth and great upper management can be hard to find in a company, but Sherwin-Williams has both of those going for it. I felt like people actually cared about me here and that I was not just an asset that could be tossed aside at any point.
cons: Retail obviously has it's challenges with crummy hours and oddly scheduled work weeks. Although it can be fairly easy for a recent college grad to become a manager and make good money quickly, it can be difficult to make significantly more money after this without a fairly big promotion (many times requiring relocation). Many managers get caught between the range of $55,000-$75,000/per year for a long time.

review_title: There were bad times, and there were worse times.
pros: It was a job when I needed it with slightly higher pay than past food. My first raise after meeting sales goals and singlehandedly signing up 50 contractors for a promotion, I was given a 32 cent raise after a year. Not 50 cents, 32. My store will make over 3 million dollars this year and there are 10 of us.
