cons: If you are part time, get another job, because you will need one. Hour scheduling is all over the place unless you are full time. For a starting pay of about $9. One week could be 17, the next could be 39. It all depends on your "average." And watch out for managers. I've had crazy managers who control everything you do, and hands off alcoholic managers that disappear. Watch out for creepy contractors who try to kiss your hand and ask you out. Because, they will. I will not be moving up in coming, just trying to pay my bills and get out ASAP.

review_title: Great Company to star your career!
pros: Great leadership. This company wants you to move up!! They have great benefits and bonuses as well. You really get to know your fellow employees and make great relationships with customers. They also pay very well.
cons: There are very few. Keep in mind that this is a paint store and depending on where you live, the winter crowd is very low. At my store I probably see only one person come in after 6 PM and most of the time they are just looking at color samples. I guess somewhere in my district they must be making a good amount of money to justify staying open until 8 PM.

pros:
-Definitely the benefits - Very generous
-Quarterly Bonuses 
-Different experiences daily
-New Challenges make the day interesting
-Matching 401k plan at 6%
cons:
-Manager and Assistant - many times that's it...no other help in store
-Long hours...12+ hour days happen too frequently due to having few unreliable part time help that is underpaid and could care less.
-Manager position is more of a worker who has management responsibilities than a manager of a store
-Work/Life - Expect to miss kids soccer games or events, no flexibility for life, mostly due to not having enough help to cover hours.
-Retail customers can be difficult to deal with. Same with commercial but less frequently.

review_title: It's alright. Has goods and bads like any job.
pros: Pretty easy stuff as far as the operational side . There is slow time during the winter season. The fast pace during the summer season is also good. Tuition reimbursement is good for those pursuing higher education. Growth within is an option.
cons: The company does a terrible job with keeping a full staff. You're expected to run a store with only two full-time people and two part-time. It would be completely doable, but later the full timers are left working really long shifts, in turn no time for personal lives. The amount of heavy lifting is not worth the toll your body will take later on. Its all a corporate game, they really have no interest in you, just selling the most they can. Because all store managers are salaried, not one of them works their actual hours, they all fake them, resulting in the asst. manager working more.

job_title: Assistant Store Manager in Dallas, TX
pros: The benefits are good and pay is decent
cons: If you work at a store where you have a lazy employees who only cares about themselves and only about  making a trip at the end of the year then this job is for you.  There are some higher ups that want to get off early every day and only work m-f so they make you as the ASM close every day you and work Tue-Sat. You might like that but if you have a life and like to get home before 8 every night then you won't like this job. Also, you have to request at least a month in advance if you want a weekend off because they make schedules 3 weeks out. Also, corporate is trying to close out on business deals and trying to save so much money that they are cutting part time hours so in turn gives you less help so your doing more work.

review_title: I love working at Sherwin-Williams! They treat me very well and pay pretty well for a first time job out of college.
pros: They start you off with a pretty good salary. I have been with the company for a little over a year and have already been promoted to a store manager. I have a great work/life balance. I just develop relationships with the customers and make sure that they keep on coming back. On top of a good salary you can earn bonus money and the better the sales the better the bonus money!
cons: I can honestly say that I do not have any cons to my job. They give me the whole store to myself and I operate it with my Assistant Manager and my part-time employees.

review_title: Hard work pays off, if you're liked.
pros: Decent salary. Great benefits. Very, very stable company. Plenty of room for advancement if you want to move all over the country at the drop of a dime every 2 years.
cons: Sherwin Williams is a very, "what are you doing for me now company." You will work very long hours (48 min you're required to be at the store). There will be high demands and you will have to answer if you don't achieve in front of your peers. Stores are extremely short staffed, (which is why managers are expected to work more than 48 hours to effectively achieve budget).

review_title: Great company to work for, but just not for me
pros: Good Salary, Great Benefits, great training program. Employees treated with respect (from my experience).
cons: Heavy Lifting, dirty work environment (but its a paint store, so duh!). I left the company because the physical nature of lifting a bunch of 5 gallon buckets of paint was too much for me. And the chemical coatings industry was not where I wanted to be career-wise long term. Nothing against the company, itself. MTP's start out in retail, but there is opportunity for growth if you want to stay with the company. There was even a mentoring type support group for women in the company. The training was thorough and I felt like they really cared about the growth of their employees, as far as the Management Training Program went.

review_title: Haven't been with SW long and already ready to get out.
pros:
Benefits
Training
Upper management
laid back
friendly work atmosphere
cons:
Open on public holidays. 
44hr work week
Low pay
No reward for hard work
Mico management
Impossible sales goals
All promotions are chosen before job postings
Incompetent life long managers who could care less and are comfortable
Almost impossibe to advance unless you relocate
You can be an assistant for 3 years before you become a manager while more experienced, and sometimes worthless assistance are chosen because they have more years under their belt.
Upper management has no idea which assistants will be better managers because they are not in the store. The interview process does not work. I have seen great assistants get passed by because they did not have 5 yrs under their belt.
Open christmas eve...really?
You can work extremely hard and reap zero benefits.
Constant price increases and budget increases.
Almost impossible to make bonus 
only 2-4% salary increases a year
Constant whining from customers about price
Stores are open about 12 hrs a day with 2FT and 1PT...calculate those hrs.
Managers work 48hrs per week with minimal salary increase from assistants

review_title: My experience working with this company since early 2017
job_title: Ft Sales Associate in Tampa, FL
pros: Good benefits, 401k plan, flexible hours in commercial locations.
cons: Wages are not enough for the amount of work you're asked for, part time hours are pretty much non existant which means FT employees are left to pick up the slack of the under staffed stores! But the biggest con is IF YOU DON'T HAVE A COLLEGE DEGREE YOU ARE NOT MOVING UP PERIOD! DOESN'T MATTER HOW GOOD YOUR NUMBERS ARE OR YOUR PAST EXPERIENCE OR YOU'RE WILLINGNESS TO RELOCATE THEY JUST DON'T PROMOTE FROM WITHIN!

review_title: My experience could have been better had I moved to a different district.
pros: Fortune 500 company. On a store level there our a lot of great individuals.
cons: Sherwin Williams states it is a family company but we work a lot of crazy hours. If you happen to be in a small store your work becomes your life. Very difficult to transfer to another district. It is very difficult to move up the corporate ladder with this company.

pros: Being open 7 days a week, it makes it easy to schedule appointments or vacations without using much time.
cons: Once you are in a retail store, you can only work within a retail store. You will work 14 hour days with no break, help, or ability to go get lunch. There is no concern for work life balance. You might get stuck with Mondays and Thursdays off. If someone calls out, you will have to work. If you are sick, you still have to go in until they could find someone to cover. If there is a blizzard, you will still be required to open the store, even in a state of emergency. Depending on your manager, you may also be forced into unethical situations.

job_title: Assistant Sales Manager in Statesville, NC
pros: I entered the Management Trainee Program right out of college. You start as a trainee and can move to an assistant manager then manager semi-quickly. I was an assistant manager when I left. The salary and benefits were good. There was an opportunity for growth (but it was much narrower than they'd have you believe).
cons: The potential for growth was very limited. It was really just working in a paint store. It was just a retail job that any high school kid could do. The biggest cons were the people I was exposed to. I am a woman and I experienced immense sexism on a daily basis from not just customers but my own co-workers and manager. I felt unsafe and very disrespected daily. They also left one person alone for hours at a time and all day long on Sundays. I felt unsafe many times. Also, our store had no security system, alarm, or cameras. Even after some theft and a break-in, the higher management refused to install any safety precautions.

pros: Working on the Product Finishes side held the greatest success in moving up and learning the B2B world. Starting as an MTP and moving up to operations manager and account manager allows you to grasp a great amount experience that is valuable anywhere. Incentives are great (when budgets are not corrected in September). Pay is good and the training that they give outside of their internal training, such as negotiation is priceless.
cons:
In the end, this company is great compared to most large fortune 500's. You work long hours, but your results can get you promoted. 

The largest con that I saw was that if you wanted to stay in a particular area, that it would be career ending. It was expected that you would move around to fill other areas. Just because you are the operations manager of a particular facility does not mean you can take over as branch manager. They would rather have you move to another state as branch manager.

pros: I was hired by Sherwin-Williams straight out of college and entered into their Management Training Program. I felt the salary and benefits I received starting at the entry level were especially generous. Every year I was with the company, I received a small raise and some years I was able to earn decent performance-based bonuses.
cons: I can testify to the fact that the stores in my district were chronically understaffed. I have heard talk that this is a company wide problem. Management was expected to fill in any gaps that resulted from the understaffing. This was a major problem considering the stores were open seven days a week. I expected to regularly lose my days off, and, even in a good week, to work well above my contracted 44hrs. The unending grind eventually led me to quit after being in my position for 4yrs.

review_title: Great opportunity employer if you put in the work
pros:
-Excellent culture, depending on what department you work in. 
-If you produce high quality work consistently, you will be recognized. You get what you deserve at this company. If you do mediocre work expecting to get a raise first before you start doing more, it's just not going to happen.
-Good benefits and 401k employer match. 
-End user support service oriented.
cons:
-Organizational/infrastructure issues which are affected by decisions made from people at the "top" who know nothing about ground-level operations because the top-down communication is poor. 
-Poor software and hardware deployment/implementation. 
-Poor change and problem management.
-Not enough investment in globalizing the technology at the company and strengthening it's IT support infrastructure. 
-Those working on deploying new technologies don't account for business critical systems enough, resulting in drastic consequences which are dealt with by the lesser-paid employees. 
-Mediocre white men tend to get promoted/valued more in IT here. Women are more likely to be scrutinized unless they excel in absolutely everything.

pros: Great pay and room for advancement if willing to relocate. You do get good training when starting in the manager training program out of college.
cons: Middle and upper management are out of touch. They tell you to sell this product but don't always look at the geographical location of each store and what the demographics are. Middle management can be very irate and disrespectful when numbers aren't better than 100%. They are very short staffed in the stores and managers must always pick up those hours. You are way over worked for even the good salary. They also don't listen to what you have to say about things. Everything is seen as an excuse of why you didn't hit a target.

review_title: Getting too top heavy and micromanaged from the corporate office
pros: Pay is fair but you can top out in your pay bracket fairly quickly. Store team can be fun and flexible.
cons:
Long hours, negligent corporate management, no profit sharing. Corporate(run largely by a bunch of white collar folks who have never run a store and who work in offices with convenient 8-4 or 9-5 shifts) makes policies and tells the managers how to operate their stores often to the detriment of morale and store function.
 Also just because the company is making more money than ever, and sales are up drastically- that profit (and bonus opportunity) is lost in the corporate world of budget increases and policy. 
44 hours is the req. for Asst. Managers, and 48 for store managers- however with hours of 7-7 and a shortage of trained staff ( lost a bunch of skilled workers when SW dropped the full time clerk position) expect to pull a lot of OT and 12 hour work days.

pros: The work I did was challenging and rewarding most of the time.  One position I held let me enjoy the sights and beauty of the United States while traveling.  The company had excellent benefits and the pay was in line for the position I held.
cons: There was too much politics.  I was overburden with my position at times because I was also doing the job as a technician.  At times there was too much emphasis on a degree instead of the experience that has been gained.

pros: Good compensation, even for part-time employees, including vacation time. Managers get quarterly bonuses based on sales, on top of a good salary. Casual environment and diverse customer base. A reasonably easy but fun job. There is a lot of room for mobility and advancement, especially for recent college graduates. And the company is crushing competitors from an environmental standpoint, always looking to make progress.
cons: Middle management sometimes impeads stores' ability to function autonomously. Also, it seems like a company this large (over 4000 stores and gobbling up competitors everyday) could provide part time employees with health insurance options, instead of spending so much time and effort into the "LiveSafe" program. There are stresses on the body and it can get rough during busy times.

pros: Good work environment, products are very solid so most sell themselves.  mostly quality people come into the store, DIY or contractor.  Managers give time off if you give them the heads up.  I like the business.
cons: Retail, open on weekends, company isn't doing well so cutting hours.  Manager isn't as solid as others.  not much opportunity for growth in the near future.  Working with DIY can be very stressful at times.  working with some contractors can be awful because of how some treat you and think they are better than you. training is basically watching training cds and getting onto the sales floor, which is the best way to learn, but is very uncomfortable for the first few weeks.

review_title: Good Potential, but Employee's Get In Their Own Way Sometimes
pros:
Most employees are good people who want to put a good product out to the customers.  The facility hits many of their goals and can tackle a project with the best of them.  The union can sometimes cause too much of an uproar about non-issues.  Overall, they do seem to have good, honest, hard working employees in spite of themselves.

Good pay for the work that is performed.

Retirement benefits are excellent.

Healthcare benefits are average.
cons:
Corporate and regional managers can implement relatively unreasonable initiatives with little/no site feedback or input.

Many things are controlled from Cleveland, not allowing creative freedom for running the operation.

review_title: Awful manager who thought I needed to "man up"
job_title: Financial Accounting Assistant in Sheffield, England
pros: Good salary, early finish on Fridays
cons: This was three years ago, but I was really prompted by the amount of press around world mental health day this year to write something. I was going through an extremely tough time while I worked here. I tried to bring this up with my manager on numerous occasions by telling my manager I had just broke up with my long-term partner, only for her to literally tell me every time to "man up" and laugh. This person was clearly unfit to manage anyone and I was frequently left with no work and left to my own devices 100% of the time, but they had been at the company a very long time so had found themself in a management position. She bought up at my review that I was miserable and never smiled, but never once bought this up outside of the review or checked on my wellbeing. Fortunately the review resulted in dismissal, which was best for everyone.

review_title: After 9 years at Sherwin- You're cannon fodder unless picked out of college.
pros:
Laid back work environment.
Friendly co-workers
Easy schedules
cons:
80% of your customers don't have high school diplomas, yet demand they know more than you.
You will not advance unless you have a college degree.
There are no "interviews" for promotions; They know who's getting the job before it's posted.
Store sales, not your performance, equate to your raises.
Senior Management wants you to work harder, but also cuts your hours in thanks.
Again, you will NOT advance here unless you have a degree.  You are just a sales monkey who works until you have had enough, then they simply replace you.

review_title: Great starter job, not a lifetime position
pros: Major company so they offer all the bells and whistles: 401k, healthcare, FMLA, Paid Vacation, etc. Incentive plans pay nicely if you're lucky enough to have a year that exceeds your expected double digit sales growth. Industry experience also a plus.
cons: Sales numbers dictate your promotions and raises. You could work your fingers down to the bone everyday but if your sales dollars don't read double digit growth then you are reprimanded for it. Long hours, very little time off, management bullies if you don't fold to their empirical demands. Staffing is always an issue due to lack of full time positions available. Relocation expected. All in a all a very demanding, thankless job.

pros: Benefits and retirement plans are great.  I advanced very quickly but I was well-liked, district management holds a lot of power over whether or not you go anywhere so whether you like the District Manager or District Sales Manager or not, you should at least be professional or you will stay an assistant manager forever.
cons: Huge conglomerate.  So many moving wheels at the highest level that senior managers are pretty out of touch.  They tend to paint with too broad of a brush, especially on economic situations.  You will be praised for doing well but it will be forgotten very quickly.  It is an old boys club, promotions and advancement come to those who play the game.

review_title: Not a good place for women or people without a degree.
pros: In most cases, the training is pretty thorough, you do have the satisfaction of really helping and coaching home owners along.
cons: Not enough employees, so often you are the only one there, which being a female with rough men contractors is a very unnerving feeling. I never felt safe. The kinds of transactions we are doing does not lend itself well to have only one or two people there at a time. It's easy to have a line create and lose customers due to not having enough time to help pick colors, choose which grade of paint, then in my case, have to manually tint and shake each gallon, ring out the customer, and deliver to car, all before ebeing able to help the next person in line.

pros:
A fairly diverse working environment consisting of Customer service and general sales obligations such as stocking, facing and fulfilling needs and orders of guests via in person interaction as well as from the company email and telephone.

Aside from Customer service and sales experience, You've the chance to interact with a warehouse and logistics like environment following the large demand of product from home bodies looking to renovate as well as general contractors and construction workers requiring large amounts of product. Overall, There is always something to interact with and learn
cons: If one is unfamiliar with manual and physical labor, even applying for customer service and entry level position implies moving one gallon to five gallon tubs of Paint, primer, gloss and base coats as well as other industrial chemicals and can be somewhat overwhelming to an unaware, or unprepared new hire.

pros:
Decent pay. 
Great benefits. 
Always learning. 
Fast paced work environment. 
Good fellow employees.
cons:
Lean. I constantly hear the question from customers, "Are you really the ONLY one here?" Management is expected to schedule very sparingly, but in turn, customer service takes a huge hit. As an assistant manager, I am expected to close pretty much every night. My manager is micro managed, so there for finds it okay to micro manage her own employees. A lot of your happiness with this company will depend on the store you are placed in. 
Morale is extremely low. Focus has switched from caring about their employees, to SALES SALES SALES. Upper management takes the stance that you are a commodity. You can easily be replaced. Veterans in the company are being edged out to be replaced by young college kids who will burn out within 2-3 years.

job_title: OTR Western Region Driver in Reno, NV
pros: Great benefits 401k match+pension and steady work.  Mileage pay is Average .4111cpm + .07200cpm per diem pay to hide less than average mileage rate.
cons: Demands 6 day a week schedule. Dispatchers waste your time at backhaul and waiting on loads. $40 truckload pay with 1 stop or 6 stops same pay. Forced dispatch no choice in loads. $5 drop n hook pay many shippers take 30 min to hour.  Lots of activity pay to hide low hourly rate for your time not driving. 15% drivers dedicated.  Seniority means nothing is avoided and hidden.

job_title: Assistant Store Manager in Silver Spring, MD
pros: Starting salary is decent and you can make quarterly bonuses which certainly helps.They also have lots of good benefits.
cons: This may be an isolated case but my manager has no leadership skills and makes it an extremely unwelcome and unpleasant work environment. Also, you don't have much say of which store they will place you after mtp program. Not much room for advancement in current situation. Aside from that there is alot of manual labor involved and there are days where all you will do is backbreaking work just to go home and pass out knowing you will do it all over again the next day. NO WORK-LIFE BALANCE. You may develop leg, knee, and back issues. Not to mention, you don't get any breaks, so you may go some days without eating.

review_title: Good starting place and you can progress rapidly if you are willing to drop everything at any time and go anywhere
pros: There is opportunity to progress rapidly.  Good benefits, good retirement program if you stick with the company for life.
cons: Not enough opportunity with in each area.  Low pay no matter what your qualifications are.   No reality between corporate and the field.  It seems as though certain things are only offered to certain people.  Also, when applying for a position in management you may not even be considered, called, or interviewed no matter your qualifications.

pros: Good benefits, great job stability, good workout if your store is busy
cons: Hours cut, sales call goals not dependent on quality but quantity, frequent price increases. Too focused on share holders and not employees and customer service, lazy managers who've all worked 10+ years, new and more company initiatives with no substance just to drive profit, upper management too disconnected from the store, budget increases but quality of work decreases b/c of part time hours cut, only 2-3% raise if you get one per year. The list could go on forever...

review_title: Good Benifits but They Make you Bleed
pros: Great health benefits!  Dollar for dollar matching funds to contribute towards a 401K deposit.  Credit Union.  Various discounts from affiliated companies.  Top notch industry and retail training. Fantastic opportunities both career wise and financially if you are a top producer.
cons: LOOOOOOOoooooooooooooooooooooong hours.  12-14 hour days, no entitlement to breaks or meals.Work weeks can be 6-7 days consistantly.  Condescending upper and middle management.  Constant threats by middle management to get the store staff to produce more with less.  Corporate politics/clicks rule the middle and upper management in this company.

job_title: Key Holder in Fernandina Beach, FL
pros: You were allowed to drive the delivery van to different job sites. They are professional but down to earth. They are a diverse company that hires different people of all backgrounds. They are great about hiring college graduates and there is opportunity to move up in the company. Usually only a limmited amount of people work at one store but can be a bad thing when requesting time off.
cons: Unless you go into the Manager Training Program, it takes effort to learn all their products. If you want to work here you must have a willingess to take the time to educate yourself. In the MTP you take classes and ate given books and binders on all the data pages and info on each product, but when you are as a sales associate you kind of learn as you go which can be stressfull.

pros: Fast-paced environment, days fly by.  Extensive product line that is industry leader.
cons: Same cons as other Sherwin Williams employee's reviews- severely short-staffed, ton of stress, and upper management is way out of touch. Morale is at its lowest in all the years I have worked for this company.  Anyone who is considering working for Sherwin Williams should be prepared to make sacrifices in their personal lives, especially if you are a manager.  It is a revolving door of employees, and since most managers are salaried it is on you to work 60-70 hours a week to make sure that the store is open.  Also, unrealistic sales budgets year after year, with threats from upper management if you don't meet goals.

review_title: Diversified Brands Division isn't what it used to be
pros: Used to be a good group to work for - they have a lot of top brands that you can work with.
cons: They don't advertise their products. . .  they are content to harvest sales instead of growing the brands.  It looks like all the Corporate efforts are focused on the Stores Group, so Diversified is left with weak leadership who doesn't really understand the business or care about their people anymore.  The entire corporate philosophy seems to have hves changed dramatically in the past 5 years.  They keep cutting back to make the bottom line look better, but that leaves everyone who is left doing way more than they have time to do.  Many things fall through the cracks and, as with every organization, the managers are only looking out for their bottom line.

pros: You get a chance to learn about a significant part of the construction/building products industry.
cons: They have a tendency to overwork fulltime employees (namely Managers) while giving very little (if any) help or resources in the form of partime employment. Partime pay is extremely low while the kind of work (though easy) is extremely taxing which makes it not feel like it is worth it. Hours are long and pay does not match the kind of money/sales you bring in.  Additionally, there is a huge diversity problem within all levels of leadership. If you are Caucasian, Male, Heterosexual and hold conservative views of the world, you will be their ideal candidate to lead.

pros: Comraderie and feeling of working for a company that appreciates the indiviual contributor as well as the Team. A company that focuses on the Safety of its employees as well as the Quality of its product. Good Benefits are a key element in the employment package at Sherwin-Williams.  I have often been told by medical and dental professionals that our package is outstanding.  401K and Company funded peosion plan are benefits that other companies have either reduced or eliminated in recent years. Stock purchase is a perk as well.  Salaries are monitored and remain competitive within the industry.
cons: Recent economic conditions have forced an extremely lean and mean operation.  Human Resources are required to do more with less.  This can be overwhelming at times but i believe this is not an SW exclusive.

review_title: Sherwin-Williams is a good place to find your career.
pros: SW has the best compensation plan in the industry.  I have worked for numerous paint cmpanies and feel that I am being as fairly compensated as I have ever been.  The salary package is competitive, not really high, but competitive.  The bonus plan is very lucrative and exceptionally well defined.  The training that we recieve has to be the best in the industry.  In two and a half years, I have been sent to three different training courses...all of which have been really helpful and well run.  Also, the retirement plan/401K program provides up a 6% match, which has enabled me to save for retirement in a very real and significant way.
cons: As a large corporation, there are times that you can feel lost in the vastness of the system.

review_title: I drove a straight box truck and I had to deliver paint and supplies to contractors.  My job title was a Hazmat Driver.
pros: The best reason to work at Sherwin - Williams is that there's always the opportunity to advance at this company.  Also, by being a full-time employee, you get a nice benefit package which includes a 401K and a pension.
cons: One of the main challenges is getting to know your customers if you're working in the warehouse.  As far as driving, everyday is different.  You always have to be aware of everything around you whole you're driving and you have to adjust your driving to mother nature.

pros: Decent pay for right out of college and good experience.  Easy to move up the ladder.
cons: To many responsibilities and no clear vision. Assistants are expected to do almost everything in the store yet meet district and corporate sales expectations. Nothing is good enough even if you do hit your goals they are always looking at what you're doing wrong. Unrealistic goals and too many initiatives to follow with very little staff and hours. If you decide to work with Sherwin be prepared for long days with little to no reward for the time you put in and lots of micro-management from higher ups.

review_title: Good opportunity and pay. Retail position.
pros: Sherwin-Williams offers a lot of room to grow. They promote from within and not solely based on seniority. Pay is great for fresh out of college. $42k base salary working 44 hours per week. Opportunity for quarterly and annual bonuses if your store does well and hits budget. Paid vacation and the company matches 6% stock purchase. Training is decent but you end up learning as you go.
cons: This is a retail position, so expect to work directly with DIY customers and contractors. Some days you may feel like you are over qualified to stand behind a register and shake paint. You work a minimum of 44 hours a week but stores are open 7am - 7pm seven days a week so expect to work evenings and weekends. Hard to take multiple days off in a row due to the retail aspect of the job. Stores are generally all understaffed.

pros: The pay and benefits are really good. You also get quarterly bonuses based on budget goals. There's also a lot of opportunity for promotion after you've been there for a year or so.
cons: The job is pretty stressful. You're expected to know anything and everything there is to know about commercial and residential painting and they don't really teach you much of it on the job. You either learn it from working with it or reading spec sheets in your free time. It's much more of a sales job than they make it seem like it is.  As an assistant you're expected to make 20-30 sales calls a week which can be anything from calling to check up on an existing customer or cold calling someone to ask for business. District management is pretty hands off. If you get a bad store manager to work with you won't have a good time.

review_title: An old school company that cares about their most valuable assest, the employees
pros:
-Competitive Pay with great benefits.
-Advancement opportunities from within are endless. Growth is up to you. The more you perform and sell, the more options you have.
-Working with a group of genuine, hard working, & great people.
-Company in good standing and has been around since the 1800's
-Continuing education options within the company
cons:
-Sometimes work/life balance is difficult
-Without a college degree advancement is slower
-Morale with lower level employees is abysmal 
-Uniforms unflattering for females
-Manual labor a must
-Clientele can be rough at times 
-Too conservative of a culture

pros: They really take care of you on a transfer. I've worked for this company 21 years and have loved it those years.
cons: The difference form working in the West Coast and now the East Cost is very disappointing. This is not the same company here. The amount of service hours used to staff a 3 million store is 8 to 10%. For the first time I have seen in several stores that phones have to go unanswered and task are put off for days due to the understaffing. It saddens and stresses me.

job_title: Assistant Store Manager in Bonita Springs, Optional[FL]
pros: I really loved everything about Sherwin. The company culture, the friendly employees, the nice customers/contractors, the benefits, opportunity for growth, etc. You can have it all at Sherwin. You will most likely have to work your way up to a position that you love but I think thats a pro, the company prefers to promote from within rather than hiring from the outside. Really the only time you'll see an outside person come into management is throughout the trainee program but their purpose for those college grads is to move up to high positions of responsibility. You may come across a hard to get along manager here and there but that happens in any business, overall it's genuinely nice people working there that are willing to help you grow.
cons: The only thing I remember disliking in the store is the extension in store hours… but then again its still a lot earlier than most retail jobs.

job_title: Management Training Program (MTP) in Jacksonville, FL
pros: No surprises, you know what you're getting yourself into.  Intially, you might think it's just a paint store, but I've never worked for a company that has the growth opportunities that Sherwin does. It's all about what you put in, and if you work hard it comes back to you double.  Everybody here is interesting as this company values a healthy work-life balance.
cons: Sometimes the stores will feel understaffed, but it's a busy industry and the retail volume at given hours can be difficult to predict.  Also, nobody likes working weekends, so hopefully your store has a few people that can rotate Saturdays and Sundays.

job_title: Part Time Sales Associate in Atlanta, GA
pros:
Part time with 401k
More interesting than standard retail
Competitive pay with yearly raise (not by much but still)
Women are (for the most part) celebrated, women only functions occasionally
Focus on promoting within company
cons:
Unfair weather policies, I lost eight hours of pay.
No training offered to part time associates, you learn in the trenches which is not always a bad thing but an in place PHYSICAL training to part time employees would be a great improvement. We have test to take online but they're confusing.
At my particular store I am required to work 28 hrs and being a student with other obligations it's tough to do that which makes me consider giving my two weeks notice
We sell heavy stuff so you have to lift heavy stuff. This is a con but I can deal for the most part
If you're a lady who likes girly things, leave it at the door if you work in the store.

review_title: Great company, but working in the stores are brutal
pros: Good pay, great benefits, chance for bonus'.  A lot of training for product knowledge and management training.  Everyone is a team player, even from store to store.  Many opportunity for advancement in a lot of different directions.
cons: Stores usually are understaffed, I've worked many 12 hour shifts with no help.  There are a few times a year that it seems like everything is thrown at us, and expectation is to go above and beyond in each thing, can be very overwhelming.  It's still retail and dealing with the general public.  Also only have 4 major holidays off, stores are open 361 days a year, 7 days a week makes it worse being understaffed.

review_title: For someone looking to get started in the job industry it's a great opportunity. Beyond that is like pulling teeth.
pros: Very fast paced, great interactions/relationships created through customers, easy to learn new processes and knowledge, can be fun to help customers transform their homes look. Feels great seeing customers so happy from our services.
cons: Long hours, low pay rate for amount done, raises (if you want call them such) are minimal at best, they expect more and more of you each moment, no chances for advancement without college degree, issues seem to get "swept under rug"

pros: Good pay and bonuses. Good place to learn management and sales right out of college. Employees are treated well.
cons:
Little advancement opportunities unless you are willing to move (anywhere in the US).  Also, there's not a lot of support from corporate and district, so you are on your own.  Ethical business practices are also not a value or concern for many managers, and district does not work hard to make sure managers are doing the right thing. 

Very bad work/life balance. Stores are not allowed to hire full time workers unless district decides they can, and since SW is very specialized knowledge, it is almost impossible to hire and keep good employees. Store and Assistant Managers end up doing most of the work. Very poor work life balance, and only gets worse when you move up to store manager.

pros: Decent pay and benefits but you learn quickly that's it not worth the stress.
cons: Rude customers that want everything there way but refuse to go to burger king to get it, understaffed stores with constantly increasing store hours. Terrible work-life balance. Not nearly enough compensation to put up with the growing list of managerial responsibilities. Upper management doesn't listen and doesn't care. Theirs not enough time in the day to meet all their expectations and they are fully prepared to add more just to make a few more bucks. If a customer complains about anything its your fault regardless of what logic and common sense dictates. If you don't have enough staff to make customers happy you need to make it happen. If someone takes a vacation be ready to come in from sun up to sun down and run the store by yourself for most of the day and greeting each customer while answering the phone, tinting paint, doing color matches, answering questions, running the register and following all the procedures.

pros: Laid back, overall very simple job. Make paint, restock items and set for delivery. There are some difficult things such as huge product selection and clients like to use them all, but you will almost always be working with someone more knowledgeable so no worries there. Real busy in the Spring -Summer months and slows down drastically in the Winter for obvious reasons. Sherwin-Williams will never go out of business, If anything they will take over all the industry.
cons: Small stores with very few employees yet the salaries are low. If they paid me more as a part-time worker I would be more motivated to stay and go through the management program.

pros: Great pay and great benefits
cons: Not enough full time positions offered to sales associates

pros: Good benefit programs, opportunity for advancement.
cons:
Never enough staff, they do not pay part time employees enough for what they are asked to do so they are constantly leaving. Because of this you are forced to work long ours burning you out. The only thing that matters is the numbers and stores are regularly fighting against each other for sales and customers like we aren’t all on the same team. It’s only gotten worse since the Valspar takeover. Honestly the core S-W stores have been tossed on the back burner since the acquisition.

Warehouses can’t keep up with production so you are constantly getting shorted on orders and having to deal with angry customers. Getting zeroed on core items is unacceptable. 2018 has been the worst year for me with this company and it’s company wide. Attitudes from customer service to the credit department have changed. Everyone is in a bitter mood. I really hope 2019 is for the better

pros: 401k, Benefits, and movement inside the company.  Each and every position is based on merit and how well you perform.  It also has a very extensive training program that keeps all the management/store staff on the same page.  The incentive plan is amazing too.  Once you start hitting your budget the company strongly rewards you.  Its is very nice getting an extra $11,000 per year.  Overall I would recommend getting involved with the Management Training Program(MTP).
cons: Long hours, customer complaints. Sometimes requires alot of patience.  There are some days which I do not get many breaks but thats how the painting business goes.  The bonus money is taxed 40% though which is kinda bad, but that is not this companies fault.

pros: You gain customer service, sales, operation, and financial experience. You management a small staff, so you are able to build lasting relationships throughout the years.
cons: Our district has been consistently short staff. The upper management turnover is high so you have to continuously prove yourself. When it comes to promotions, they already have the person in mind so there is no need to apply if you didn't receive the telephone call to apply. There is no transparency. Sales and the pressure to open up new charge accounts are the number one priorities currently. Rain, sleet, hurricane, and snow...we are open. They preach safety but they want the store open. Absolutely no work life balance when the whole district is short staff.

pros: Great pay, good benefits, bonuses, relatively simple work.
cons:
Will "force resign" you for being tardy by one minute. Will not listen to reason or explanation.
Will attempt to force FMLA usage for one or two sick days.
Several managers do not care about their employees or coworkers, only about themselves.

I worked for this company for eight years and my wife worked for them for two and a half years. I resigned due to terrible upper management and she was force resigned for tardiness, despite faithfully commuting nearly 80 miles round trip every day. From store management to senior management to Human Resources, this company has all but castrated its loyal work force. Several years ago, this company seemed to care about its employees. No longer.

review_title: Great company, great employees, not so great pay
pros: Chance to meet very good people on both sides of the counter, learn a lot about paint and other things that can help with personal projects, pretty cheap paint, variety of things to do around the store which keeps the job interesting. The company has great benefits as well as many company paid extra curricular activities.
cons: Starting pay for part and full time is low compared to other positions in the area. The starting pay for stocking at Target is $12.50 where I make $10 after 3 years as part time employee. A friend worked full time for 5 years and quit around $12. Those figures do not compensate employees for the work they are required to do.

pros: They take care of their employees when it comes to benefits, opportunities for quick advancement if willing to move, very challenging and rewarding work, 401k match, and pension  (extremely difficult to find)
cons: Poor work/life balance, focus is only on profits  (purely raising the stock price as it is part of a corporate initiative, which is undoubtedly a good thing to a point, but it seems to be a real push to benefit baby boomers as they retire and make it difficult on millenials to build any real equity in the company), and as an expectant father I am only awarded a baby day for my paternity leave, way far behind many, many companies in the US and all companies in Europe, I will have to take vacation or unpaid time (FMLA) off of work so I can insure I can take my wife to the hospital and take her and my new child home.

pros: Great pay, great benefits, laid back company with management not breathing down your neck. Promotions are quickly given IF, BIG IF you take advantage during your window (if you aren't interested in moving up early in the process, they tend to overlook you for future positions). Teaches you how to essentially run your own business, become more sales oriented, overall a great entry level job.
cons: Blue collar job so heavy physical labor. Technically still retail so you have to deal with all the cons that come with that (open 7 days a week, clocking in and out, uniform, cleaning, customer service, managing employees, etc.). Will vary based on district but favorites are being picked for promotions which sometimes is baffling.

review_title: Solid company to work for, great benefits, cut-throat sales at times with high expectations.
pros: Benefits, starting pay, good co-workers, ability to move up quickly, ability to relocate, industry leader, stability, great training, rewards for high sales including trips and bonuses
cons: Fairly high pressure for sales reps and store managers, unreasonable expectations for sales, ignores economic conditions when setting sales goals, methods and consistency don't matter if you aren't hitting your budgeted goals

review_title: great company, great products, great benefits, low pay and an abundance of bad managers
job_title: Sales Service Representative in Cary, NC
pros: great company, great products, great benefits, ability to move up fast if willing to relocate to remote middle of nowhere places for a while.   if your able to get a good manager than your golden.
cons:
somewhat low pay if your a college grad that owes student loans.  Also an abundance of bad managers

this is a great company but unfortunately  i've had one god awful manager after the next,  each one has only ever worked at sherwin williams and has never worked another job.  None have a college degree and all have no outside perspective.  All have been an HR nightmare.

pros: Good people and learn a lot about business operations
cons: Sherwin Williams is a large company and that was attractive to me as a college grad and upper management preaches that it’s mostly internal growth. So I came in as an MTP and put in my time in hopes to eventually get a corporate job. No. Once you start on the retail side it’s basically impossible to go corporate and the select few that do end up doing soft skill positions such as recruiting or HR. You are pigeon held in the retail sales field and once I finally realized that I left. So don’t let them fool you by saying you have a chance at corporate because you really don’t if you come in as an MTP.

review_title: Great Company and Great benifits but sometimes stressful and overwhelming
pros:
Staff is nice
The company takes care of their employees
Always busy especially in summer hours
Some manual labor of unloading the truck
cons: Can be stressful when dealing with customers that need more help when there is a line to the door, and all the customers give you dirty looks. So busy sometimes in summer it is overwhelming between listening and helping with customer complaints, issues with paint, and making orders when the store is full constantly. lots of customers with un realistic expectations for some paint, lacquer and stain matches. Lots of customers ask for your professional help, but then refuse to listen and tell you that what you're saying is wrong. Never had time to take a lunch in summer time, always to busy and no set lunch break, only get one when customers are not in the store or when the other employees could deal with them.

review_title: Changing culture makes it far more a numbers game...people very much second
pros: Very strong organization and robust history. A lot of employees stay a long time
cons: The recent change in CEO and the drive to specific share price, sales and profit has changed the culture of the organization to being a lot more ruthless and cut throat. It rewards success but the goals to be successful and pay out bonuses has become ever more challenging. The people were the strength of the company and now too many walk on egg shells.

review_title: So many reasons to spread my wings & fly far, far away!
pros: Coworkers, customers, benefits, tools & resources available
cons: Poor management selection (embarrassing actually) & promotion strategies, Feelings of being undervalued & unappreciated, Technology, Micromanaging, Unrealistic expectations, Unethical practices with employees & customers, & the disconnect from what SW touts to potential new hires about culture, family, etc, and how it really is.  BIG WARNING: If you want to move up in this company, prepare to MOVE & BE SINGLE (or you will become single).  ALL NEWLY PROMOTED PEOPLE ARE SINGLE WITHOUT FAMILIES.  SW DOES NOT ALLOW PROPER WORK-LIFE BALANCE, ALTHOUGH THEY'LL CERTAINLY TELL YOU HOW IMPORTANT FAMILY IS.   It's the SW dirty little secret!

job_title: MTP Assistant Manager in Destin, FL
pros: pay, health/vision/dental benefits, and the Sherwin Williams culture. Good training on running a small business and great for entry level growth. I started as a Manager Trainee and was placed as an Assistant manager instantly. They promote within the company so you can easily move up the ladder if you are willing to move.
cons: if you are relocated to a smaller store.. you might not have enough part-time help . you and the manager will do majority of the work.. which can be physically and mentally draining with lots of working over time. Also, with any company.. there are a lot of rules. you must incorporate everyday routines while abiding to polices and procedures. I am a small framed female and it is definitely a physically demanding job. There has been days where i feel so overwhelmed and exhausted.. mixing upward to 100gallons a day. It takes a certain type of person working for this job

pros: Good corporate culture, management, sales reps, DMs everyone gets along pretty well. Pay is better than most companies in the coatings world, benefits too. If you bonus out you can make out pretty well.
cons: Mostly dealing with customers in the store, either contractors or DIY. Some days feel kind of rewarding, other days are long and you can get some seriously terrible customers who treat you like garbage. If you are not hitting your numbers its your fault according to upper management (some of the best managers i know never hit budget because of their location, and it just wore them out)

pros: Good pay and benefits, a company with a good reputation and a product that backs it up.  A bonus program that when met can mean a decent check in your pocket.
cons: Production and shift work (especially when you get stuck on third shift) Having rules that are classified as cardinal rules (meaning violation "can" get you fired) which are no different than regular guidelines of employment.  Being held to production guidelines when there isn't enough work to legitimately reach your production requirements in a shift.

review_title: Good Job to Get Through College
pros: Better than average part time pay and generally they were fairly flexible with my school schedule, I also got a company matched 401k and paid vacation time each year.  Overall a pretty good job.
cons: Very small staff in each store makes it difficult to call out sick if you need to as it places a great strain on those who are working.  Also for the pay they expect a lot more out of you than most and you only get one raise a year which isn't much.  I have worked for four years and I started at $10.50 and I just now got a decent raise to 11.80 because I took on more reasonability and became a key holder.  They really work you to the bone when you are on the lower tier.

job_title: Assistant Store Manager in Columbus, OH
pros: Decent Pay, like owning your own business, good people to work with.  Cliche as it may seem, this job is what you make of it.  As long as you are surrounded by quality staff, you can climb the ladder in a relatively short amount of time.
cons: Stores are open 7 days a week, winters can be very boring.  Depending on the DM that is your area, you can feel very valued or very undervalued.  The difference in a good DM and a poor DM completely changed by perspective of the company in the final 2 years I was with the company.

review_title: Overlook good employees, even ones with degrees, in order to satisfy diversity standards.
pros: Good job throughout college, works with schedule, descent pay for a student, good benefits with 401k
cons: Unfair to good employees by hiring new students fresh out of college that have to be trained by people that have been loyal to the company for years and know far more and are just as capable as the recent college graduates. Even someone working with the company for years with a degree may be overlooked in order to satisfy diversity demands. Managers used to be able to actually manage their own stores now you basically have to fill out a report for everything you do almost like the employees are puppets. Stays open very late on weekdays and open Saturday and Sunday all day. Hard for managers to have a good work/life balance.

review_title: Overall a great company to work for.
pros: The pay is fairly decent, especially for a recent college graduate with 0 experience in the industry. They value education and allow stores to make their own decisions. The hours are decent, 44 hours a week but most stores close at 7pm the latest which is not to bad. Sherwin-Williams employees are more loyal than any I have seen. Most of the people I have met have been with the company many years and are not complaining about it. Finally, they have excellent training programs, they are not cheap. They really do invest in their employees and they really believe in promoting from within.
cons: You will likely have to relocate. They are not shy about letting you know. It's probably the second question they ask you... maybe the first.

review_title: A good place to get a good start and run a business with the support of a Fortune 500 company.
pros:
-Great Benefits
-Good People
-Good District Management
-Great opportunity for advancement if you are woman, minority, etc. A downside if you do not fit these requirements.
-Tuition reimbursement
cons:
-If you aren't in the inner circle, you are out
-Promotions often don't seemed based off of merit.
-There is absolutely no transparency/honesty. Although, the new district management team is much better

review_title: The truth about working for Sherwin-Williams
pros: Good wage, benefits, plant location.
cons: Sherwin-Williams announced at Christmas time 2015 the closure of the Vancouver manufacturing plant and head office effective March 31,2017. General paint was in business for over 100 years! Hundreds of jobs have been lost since Sherwin-Williams acquired General Paint corporation. No  culture at this location since Sherwin Williams took over. CEO John Morikis is quoted in the HBSDEALER magazine (November/December 2016) Vol. 42 No.10 saying the following "I want to make something explicitly clear, we do not buy companies to dismantle them"  The Vancouver manufacturing plant is shutting down on March 31,2017 and all the general paint stores have been converted to Sherwin-Williams stores. Isn't this dismantling a company?  Once again a large American company has shut down Canadian operations and laid off hundreds of Canadian workers that were making a good wage. Please support our Canadian paint companies like Cloverdale Paint.

job_title: Sales Associate in Los Angeles, CA
pros: This job is very easy once you learn the ropes. Overall, the atmosphere within the store is chill and my co-workers are pretty awesome, but the store dynamic really depends on the people you work with. Luckily, my manager is pretty flexible and our store staff is rather large so scheduling things like vacation time is simple. I started as an MTP and got promoted to assistant manager fairly quickly and the pay and benefits are good. When I asked for a job transfer because I was going back to school, I took on a part time position which is where I am now.
cons:
- Customers can be difficult/rude
- MTPs are often shuffled around from store to store and not promoted for months depending on the district
- This company is big on relocation, so if you aren't willing to move if they ask, you may get left behind

pros: They are a stable company that still has a pension plan for employees.
cons: They do not get rid of bad employees, especially incompetent and abusive managers. They don't really care about employees and managers are allowed to do whatever they want to employees with impunity. It's probably OK to work there if you have a good manager, but it you don't, it can be hell going into work every day. They are stingy giving vacation time. You can't use sick time if you r chile is sick or if your spouse is in the hospital. Benefits are on the low end of average.

review_title: Sherwin-Williams: Great place to start a career.
pros: Great training program for entry level sales people. Most promoting comes from within.  It really depends on what district you work in, but I love working in the Washington DC area. Great flow of information from management to employees.  As a sales rep, I have a lot of freedom to run my territory the way I choose as long as my numbers are good. Good base pay with uncapped earning potential.  Even in this tough economy, SW still takes great care of their employees. A lot of the competition are laying off employees, while SW is giving raises and paying dividends.
cons: Districts often compete with each other for business.  Male dominated industry.

review_title: Good Start, Company Turned for the worst
pros: Great retail experience. Tons of knowledge to gain. Pay was at par. Good experience while attending college.
cons: Company culture went down the drain.  Lay offs, reduced employees per store, increased store hours, all while denying any form of overtime.  Managers are salary based so they can get away with it.  Plus they are turning store employees and managers into sales representatives by requiring so many calls to customers per week and monitored like a hawk, which can be VERY difficult when required sometimes working a store by yourself due to said changes.  With a "no excuse" attitude, and claiming stores are "properly staffed", which they are not, they no longer care about their employees.  Very disappointed with the changes over the years.

pros:
- As an intern you  get great insight on what you would be doing if you were to choose the company after graduation.
- A lot of hands on and not just sitting at a desk all day.
- They give you the opportunity to get out into the field with a rep several times during your internship.
cons:
Your manager can make or break the internship
Sometimes management isn't always on the same page in regards to what is going on in your internship.
If you are looking for 40 hours per week you have to be lucky enough to get placed at a high volume store.

pros: Stable company with very few large competitors
cons:
-Poor communication skills across company. Often times meetings are more self congratulatory presentations for the higher ups.

-Incredibly political! You're friends at work or on Facebook will reflect how you grow in the company. This will even be brought up in your performance.

-Unspecific and unmeansured ever changing goals

-Often hold mantadory training without giving the employee the proper tools to follow along

-Secure company does not mean job security! Sherwin cam put someone on "probation" at their banners rebiew. The performance improvement plan is basically a process where they strong arm the employee to quit. The employee gets notified he or she is on probation. They have two weeks to improve, ot they can quit with a "severance bonus." If you try to shape up, and don't, you're fired without any pay. If the employee takes the first option of  resignation, he or she has to sign a document agreeing not to sue for wrongful termination.

-Roaches everywhere

-Staff in "Corporate" side are treated much better than the "Domestic" side.

review_title: Ultimately they will discard you once they do not need you anymore
pros:
Autonomy
Good pay
Good benefits
Challeging work
Decent immediate management
cons:
Upper Management is terrible
Once they are done with you, you will be discarded like an old towel
Beware of them trying to move you to another location. Once you do it they may "eliminate your job" screwing your whole world up
Upper managment no longer cares for the people at the bottom doing the work. It is all about the bottom line even when the company is profiting.

review_title: A good job with career potential
pros: Better pay than other paint companies. Freedom to run the store the way you wish, as long as you are successful. Sherwin-Williams has the best reputation with the contractors--makes selling easier. S-W sells quality products, trains and maintains knowledgeable staff. Co-workers take pride in their jobs. Culture of fun at work--depends on your supervisors, of course.
cons: Can be a super physical job. Slinging lots of five gallon pails and making drywall mud deliveries may be a problem for some people-you don't need to get a gym membership if you work at a high volume store. Large portion of the contractors are immigrants--at times commucation and differences in cultures can be an issue. Speaking Spanish would be valuable but we also had customers who were Russian, Polish, Indian, Vietnamese, Korean...

review_title: Not bad, but you better be an A+ multi-tasker
job_title: Assistant Branch Manager in Gilroy, CA
pros:
Not bad for pay as a new ASM
Great atmosphere in store as a rule.  Management deals fairly with subordinates.
ASM's usually have AWESOME schedules, IF the store has all the keyholders, managers and associates required.  NO NIGHT SHIFTS!!!  I was usually on the road home by 6:15pm.
Decent training program.
Ability to truly run your own store as you see fit.  They embrace employee innovation to the fullest (usually).
cons:
Stress like never before!  Expect to deal with 3-4 customers' orders at once, all of them on tight deadlines
Extreme level of competency required on all product lines.  You need to learn to become a walking encyclopedia on the products and uses.

job_title: Assistant Store Manager in Edenton, NC
pros: Comparatively good pay. Depending on store the staff can work as a team and get along well. Good vacation time.
cons: Corporate micromanaging, division wide blanket sales drives with no consideration to rural or regions of stores (e.g. Required to make 60 calls a week out of all stores, however some rural stores only had 27 accounts on their 60 calls a week list). The constant promotions to grow the DIY sector are causing rifts over pricing with contractors. Long hours which are a drain on the back page for profit and yet store held accountable to keeping expenses down.

review_title: Good at first. Bad 4 years later
pros: Good benefits for part time such as vacation hours. Flexible with scheduling
cons: Very understaffed. This is not just from working at one store but seems to be a trend throughout Sherwin. Especially on weekends and from around 4-close there will be only one employee there. Weekends are especially bad because that one employee is there by themselves for the entire weekend. This means no real breaks for that employee. Not sure how Sherwin gets away with working and employee for 10 hours without a break but they do. And on top of that a low pay. Been with the company for 4 years and new hires at Walmart make more than me.

review_title: Good pay and benefits but a poor schedule
pros: great pay and benefits for a full time entry level position. at my store at least I had some say in the scheduling of myself and the other manager and part time employees.
cons: days are long and can be boring at times. store is open 7 days a week and someone has to be there at all times. most of the time it will be one of the managers since the part time employees are only allowed so many hours a week and you typically will need them during the week. working the weekends become a drag after a while.

pros: This company has provided me with multiple opportunities and the doors are always open to talk to upper management.  I like the commraderie that is shown when we work together, we have no limits on what we can accomplish.  The company really seems to take an interest in you as a person rather than just an employee that works for them.
cons: LONG hours and ignorant customers, but it is retail and sales so there isnt much that SW can do about that.  Long periods of time to wait for bonus compensation and reimbursement checks for expenses, something new has to happen in regard to this, as it becomes really annoying.

pros: Great Benefits and Resources
cons: High turnover of part- timers because they do not provide enough hours.   The company expects the  Managers to get everything done with little help.  They refuse to give assistant managers more hour to help the  manager when  the store is short- handed. Customers will have to wait for a long time to be serve  because there is not enough help and part- timers are limit to certain amount hours they can work for the week.  It seems they are more concern about numbers and making money than the quality of work  life for  their employees.

pros:
It is flexible, but this is really on a case by case basis.
You can pretty much never get fired.
Bonus is fairly achievable and can be quite lucrative 
Do get a chance to work with a lot of interesting people, both inside and outside of the company.
Benefits are top notch
cons:
Work life balance, especially as you move up. 
The expectation really becomes that you must sleep, eat, drink, and live paint. 
Upper management claiming that they have your back in any situation then the second that a customer complains (correctly or no) they will fall to the customer's whim. 
You can either choose to have a family and an average salary or choose to move up and never have any chance to see your kids/significant other.

review_title: Kill the chicken for the eggs?
job_title: Assistant Store Manager in Toronto, ON
pros: Fast promotion if you know how to suck upper management axx, genuinely enthusiastic and knowledgable co-workers, benefits offered after 1 month for full-time employees.
cons: Biased and blinded management, unexperienced senior/store managers promoted based on personal preference instead of qualification; strict hierarchy system (some self-named "superior" have obvious privileges or double-standards); extremely ruthless long hours (easily over 48 hours with full weekend availability expected); minimum working ethic (as long as you bring sales and head office likes you, no body can touch you even for harassment, breach of policy, discrimination, etc.)

review_title: Sherwin-Williams no longer cares about independent stores...Lowes is the new SW
pros: 6 percent 401k match, Pension, Health Insurance has a high deductible  and also the dental is hard to find anyone in network
cons:
HOURS
WORK-LIFE BALANCE
Pay is low when you break down the hours you put in
Lack of grown
Lack of accountability at the top

pros: I started as an intern then stayed on as a part-time sales associate. I was pleasantly surprised by how much I like working at Sherwin Williams. It's a very casual work environment, and I love the people I work with, which is a pretty diverse group of individuals.
cons: It seems like the only way to get information about what's going on in the company is through the grapevine, so there's a lot of gossip and talking behind people's backs. It also seems like the upper management change things simply for the sake of changing them, which is just an inconvenience for the people who work in the retail stores. The uniformity of the stores can be a positive, but sometimes it's just a nuisance and impractical.
