pros: If you are in a good store with good quality people it can be a fun place to work. Their is a wide variety of work and it's varied enough to stay interesting. Many of the regulars or contractors are good people and great to build a relationship with.
cons:
The work culture was very dependent upon what store you were in. I chose not to enter the Management Training program because the pressure to grow sales was not balanced with a supportive management or price points that could bring success. It seemed like the successful reps and market managers were the ones willing to bend the rules or cut corners. Not something I wanted to make a career out of.
- Retail hours with retail pay.

pros: It's a steady job that is hard to get fired, there are days where you'll have 3-4 hours of downtime between customers, so if you stay caught up with your duties, the job isn't difficult.
cons: There used to be a tv playing for customers until upper management axed it. Stores are open 7 days a week & only closed on the big holidays, New Years, Thanksgiving, Christmas. Now open until about 4 on 4th of July, Labor Day, Christmas Eve, you get the idea. Opening hours are being extended during "Super Sales" on friday & monday of sale untill 8, not very family friendly. Typically a skeleton crew is used at store, because that is all that SW allows, very strict on overtime.

pros: Good Pay, great benefits!
cons:
You will be married to a paint store. You will probably have to work every 3 day weekend because you can't afford the part time man hours (your Assistant Manager can only work 44 hour/week, leaving you to fill the rest).
You are salaried to work 48 hours a week, and don't get paid for the hours you work over this (one month I averaged 73 hours/week).
About 4 times a year, SW has a super sale, which means your store is open for an additional hour.
The work is physically taxing and mentally exhausting.
It's not so bad for a first job out of college, but don't expect to make a career out of being a store manager.

pros: Great learning experience with fair compensation. Excellent retirement benefits.
cons: As a manager you will be expected to give everything you have today, and find a way to give more tomorrow. Everything is based on location, if you work in an old store with new ones popping up all around you, prepare yourself for an uphill battle. If you get to take over a new store prepare for less work, more money, and an almost guaranteed trip to Hawiai. My advice is To be selective!!!!

pros: There are no pros for working at this company. I honestly can't think of any.
cons: Where to begin.. awful management, major favoritism to those who flirt and touch customers, HR doesn't care about you and only cares to protect the company, customer are rude and vulgar yet upper management lets it slide because it's a sale for them, long hours, working every weekend (at least in my store,) the worst people to ever work with, everyone legit tells on each other like we are in kindergarten, lots of backstabbing and fakeness. This was in New Jersey. I'm not sure how it is in other locations. But do yourself a favor.. if you went to college and have a degree, do NOT work retail, especially at Sherwin Williams. Also, there is NO work life balance. Save yourself from this company!

review_title: I enjoy my job As a Delivery driver, Some don't.
pros: You get to drive around all day and don't have a boss riding you to work harder. As long as your deliveries are done in a timely manner no one will get on your case.
cons: It's nearly impossible to get full time as a delivery driver at Sherwin-williams. There are 2 in my region and no plans for anyone else to get it anytime soon. You will also get paid next to nothing but the benefit of not having to deal with a boss breathing down your throat is the trade off.

review_title: Decent job if you are single and don't mind having any weekends to speak of.
pros: Good pay and good benefits.
cons: Weekend hours are unjustifiable,8 to 5 on Saturday and 10 to 4 on Sunday, very unfair to employees who have families or are church goers. Upper management is very ungrateful and disrespectful to store employees. My manager has made just as much money for SW in a 1.5 mil store as most 3 mil and up stores do in his 21 years of service and he is treated as if he is worthless. Price is always going to be an issue.

pros: Good experience in all areas of a business.
cons:
As a manager they continue to expect more and more with less and less. They would rather have 2 FT employees and 8 PT employees, instead of balancing it out with FT employees that would care a little more about the job. 
Continual turnover. 
No matter how good you've ran your store, always a sense of upper mgmt hinting at not needing you, that there are other people out there that can do your job. 
Only concern is sales. Cutting expenses doesn't mean anything... motto is sell sell sell, and if you're not, then you're of no use to them.
Store mgmt is expected to be a 2nd sales rep while being responsible for all aspects of the store.

review_title: Flexible when you need it, but no room to grow.
job_title: Assistant Store Manager in Philadelphia, PA
pros:
Easy to schedule around things you need to do out of work.
You don't need to be a rocket-scientist to do well.
Slow in the winter, so there is time to job search.
cons:
Poor pay unless you are in a profitable store.
Management is apathetic to plight of those lower than a Store Manager.
Poor communication, everything remains a secret until the last minute and when you are told something, there is no time to adjust.
Inept senior management holdovers from the takeovers of Duron and MAB.

review_title: Great Learning Experience. Not for most
pros: Store employees can be a pleasure to work with. Great benefits and 401K options. Promotions are available but its a very linear ladder.
cons: For what is expected pay is exceptionally low. Lead generation sales calls make it almost impossible to concentrate on managing your store. Especially the quantity that are required on a weekly basis. That said, most stores are understaffed which compounds the problem. Long hours, difficult clientele, and did i mention pay is not nowhere near what it should be for what is expected. No company parties, nothing at all. Really? How do you keep a team environment when there's no interaction.

review_title: Good place to work but watch out for bureaucracy
pros: The company takes time to make sure that all employees are up to date on the latest and greatest product offerings. Furthermore their training (although boring and tedious) is helpful when you are trying to help a homeowner. This is a service job so you will be dealing with customers but in general Sherwin seems to promote the right people to run the stores.
cons: This is a large corporation and you will fill out paperwork... a lot of paperwork for everything you do. Furthermore, even at the lowest level you are expected to be able to juggle tasks that may far outweigh your pay grade (e.g. large orders for industrial coatings and the like)

pros: Consistent Hours, Better than Average pay for position of its skill level, Stock bonuses, customers were nice
cons: High volume made training new employeees difficult, Outdated POS System that hindered business at times, Managment with EXTREME people skills deficincies (got called stupid for trying to make  sure someone PAID FOR SOMETHING, yelled at in front of customers for doing nothing wrong) Their opinions of you/your work seemed to change with their moods, and they also seemed to view any statement above an eighth grade vocabulary level or slight change in voice tone as "sarcastic/facetious"

job_title: IT Project Manager in Cleveland, OH
pros:
* Pay is decent.  
* Company is stable and financially healthy.  
* Most people go in, do their work, go home on schedule.  It varies by job and cyclical activities or projects that can cause spikes in workload and time, but many people put in the standard 40.
cons:
* Very traditional.  Group-think is common.  Culture is often adverse to change. 
* Leadership is mostly middle age white males, and there doesn't seem to be a feeling that it's weird and not good.

review_title: Work values are going down the drain.
pros: Starting out it was a great experience. Co-workers were a pleasure to be around, never minded coming to work every day, management looked out for you.
cons: Store staffing has been drastically reduced to 3 people per store AND increasing store hours, forcing employees to work alone. This has become a security issue for current employees, not to mention little to no life/work balance since all stores are now open from 7-7 (with rumors of soon to become 7-8). Furthermore, current employees are denied a promotion despite having years of experience with the company. They would rather someone fresh from college with no experience in retail whatsoever.

pros: Decent pay for entry level job. Benefits are also decent. Nothing out of the ordinary with the exception of stock.
cons: The training here is terrible. There is little to no formal training and is completely reliant on store staff. Since I've started I've received tons and tons of contradictory information from managers which makes it exceptionally difficult to develop any sort of consistency. Store culture is terrible. As an MTP you are basically just passed the buck of all assistant duties that they don't want to do. No accountability. Completely cater to customers even when rude or out of line. Spend most of my days stocking shelves and cleaning.

review_title: With the good comes the bad.
pros: Benefits (401K, stock, etc.). Closed a few days out of the year. Bonuses. Relocating is always an option since the company is so big. Pay is decent. Great place if you love sales and don't care to be home much.
cons: Pay does not compensate for the responsibilities. Politics and favoritism. Sales determines everything...but the company works against you most of the time (takes your clients away and gives them to other stores to make the numbers look good). Short staffed. Open too many hours- nights, weekends, and most holidays. Trying to make a specialty store like a big box store.  Zero work-life balance. Store always comes first.  There is no "calling off" without repercussions.

pros: Nice co-workers, lots of things to learn. Hours are flexible and unlike other retail jobs, you never work past 7pm. Having retired from a large corporate environment, I would say anyone who is motivated and has half a brain could move up in this company.
cons: Inconsistent experience depending on your store management. My managers had no customer service skills, although they were nice to me. There was absolutely ZERO TRAINING. This problem was amplified because our store was under staffed and no one was able to take the time to show me anything. For a low paying part time gig, I had to do a lot of my own research and organizing.

pros: Able to manage projects, help clients with painting questions, great training program, great culture, the job itself was really fun and different.
cons: The ONLY reason I left was because of the work life balance. There were times I worked open to close 10 days in a row. If you're short staffed, it's on you to run the store. Which is stressful when you have a line of customers out the door waiting for product.

review_title: good long term career, if you like sales
pros: love the people of SW, cant beat it! If you've been working for 5+ yrs, you remember the good/fun times.  Great learning experiences.  Opportuntiy to grow and use your brains to run your store, with lots of help from corporate.
cons: too many sales drives, flip-flopping agendas, little to no holidays off. Lots of college grads with entitlement issues entering the company, most never make it past assistant manager.

review_title: Culture, Opportunity for Growth and Philanthropic Contribution
pros: During my search for the perfect opportunity by which I could build a career, I visited, and informally interviewed many employees to get their take on the position, company, and life that resulted as a whole. Regardless of whether he was a janitor, or well-established in the upper rung in the corporate hierarchy, I could not find anyone with anything negative to say. The pay and benefits? Fantastic for entry-level and people who work well, are promoted 1-3 positions every few years from the information I gathered. I've just begun, but it appears to be the best choice I've made.
cons: None, so long as you aren't adverse to providing excellent service and lifting gallons of paint (who needs a gym membership? 🤗)

job_title: Sales Associate in Grand Rapids, MI
pros: During my time as an employee here I met some incredible people. Some times it was my customers, sometimes a new employee. Even though this was just a part time job through college, many of these people I still talk to today (professionally).
cons:
-Low compensation
-Corporate in 2016 cut the amount of employee hours each store can use each week, which put an incredible amount of strain on the managers and part-time employees.
-District management was disorganized and unwilling to learn from it's mistakes.
-Had 3 instances in 4.5 years where my paycheck just went missing and would take an entire second pay period to receive that prior paycheck.

job_title: PC Sales Representative in Philadelphia, PA
pros: 401k and Pension Plan are great
cons: Things are done on a need to know basis. Once you get in with the company, there are a lot of politics and red tape that prevent you from acheiving your budget. They will tell you there is no Bonus CAP, when in reality they limit your total potential earnings by not allowing you to open new accounts in certain areas and by not allowing you to call on certain customers.

job_title: Sales Representative in Saint Paul, MN
pros: When I started it was great.  They allowed you to run things they way that works for you and see results.
cons: As time went on, available part time hours allowed were very little.  You had 3 or more people micromanaging you.  My sales manager was suppose to be my boss but the city manager would ride a long and act as my boss and and contradict what the sales manager told me.  They promote people who tell them what they want to here instead of people who get results.

pros: Great medical benefits, the 401k plan, the pension and opportunity for advancement. There are many locations located throughout the world in which to transfer or promote to.
cons: The salaries are no where near competitive to other paint companies for their management staff. The bonus program is virtually unattainable and has been changed to reflect more unrealistic figures to benefit the company.

job_title: Assistant Store Manager in Indianapolis, IN
pros: Great 401k matching, fairly easy promotions, good health benefits
cons: Its retail. Be prepared to work weekends, odd hours, and generally a high stress environment.  For a college grad, having to work behind a counter and where polo shirts with khakis can be a little demeaning. Retail customers are not a great crowd, and your commercial customers (mostly painters) can be a pretty rough crowd. Store hours and promotions are trying to compete with big name home improvement stores.  They are going after the retail market, which means longer hours and less flexibility.

review_title: This is a decent company to work for if you want something part-time, and good benefits
pros:
The company cares about it's employees
An environment committed to excellence
Responsibilities that are rewarding
Good products are easy to sell with confidence
Very good customers and co-workers (in my experience)
Retirement plan
cons:
The nature of this job is very tedious. (with colors, application directions, and explaining directions to customers- very often, you'll say the same things over and over)
Customers that complain about your service or products at their own fault is typical.
Some products smell really bad, and you must work with them on a regular basis

job_title: Financial Customer Service Representative in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Good pay coming out of college, good benefits, opportunities to move up in the company and around the country, stable company and my work/life balance has been great (but i don't have children or anything)
cons: A sales rep once told me about this company "you wont get rich, but you'll never have to worry about losing your job," which is very true, when i worked in the stores the hours kind of sucked but I've seen much worst in retail mgmt. I've got small gripes here and there but overall I'm happy I work here.

review_title: Competitive sales company with no work life balance.
job_title: Commercial Sales Representative in East Saint Louis, IL
pros: Competitive salaries and advancement opportunities if you're willing to relocate. Forward-thinking company with Green Technology and always on The Cutting Edge of what's next in the industry.
cons: No work-life balance and too much pressure on good performers to move on after 2 years. As soon as someone got comfortable and successful if you didn't look to the next step then you were on the hot seat. Sometimes it's okay to leave employees in a position if they are successful and happy.

job_title: Financial Customer Service Representative in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Good pay coming out of college, good benefits, opportunities to move up in the company and around the country, stable company and my work/life balance has been great (but i don't have children or anything)
cons: A sales rep once told me about this company "you wont get rich, but you'll never have to worry about losing your job," which is very true, when i worked in the stores the hours kind of sucked but I've seen much worst in retail mgmt. I've got small gripes here and there but overall I'm happy I work here.

pros: Paint contractors appreciate on time deliveries-Sherwin has good paint
cons: Poor managers-Position has gone to their heads and they act like dictators-they lie alot to make themselves look good-they talk bad about customers behind their backs-they believe in cronyism-If you are related to someone higher up in the company the manager treats them like royalty but if you are a regular part timer they degrade you everyday - Please stay away from HR-they are great when you call them until they gather information to be used to degrade you-they are not employee friendly-BEWARE

review_title: Bad place to start a career. Deadend Job
pros: Easy to be hired. Simple interview. Standard working hours.
cons: Bad people management. Managers do not have any emphaty towards workers especially juniors executive. No orientation for new hire. No training given for the job. Everything have to be learned on the go and seniors executive was not helpful instead finding mistakes of the juniors and put them down. I personally feel so drained and this place killed qmy spirit. Bad company culture will minimum benefits while at the same time expecting the employee to put the extra “miles”. Highly not recommended for people who have bigger goals in life. But if you like a routine job with stable minimum income. You are welcome here.

pros: They train employees very well. Good pay. Good training cds.  Were good to work for the majority of he time.  Kept store fairly clean.
cons: Working Sundays was a big downside. Over price things. I would guess around 60 percent margin mark up. I had to use my personal vehical for work related things. I felp like they should have reimbursed me for mileage or somethig like that. Too slow in advancing newer employees. Never had casual Friday or on weekends. Had problems with Payroll in giving me the money I was entitled to. No training on faux finishing so we could help custoers in that area.

pros: Great dealing with customers, practicing sales techniques, and being able to personally discuss objectives with higher management persons.
cons: Pay. Being that I'm at 3rd key holder, meaning I take on the responsibility of opening, closing, bank deposits, etc, and get paid under $10/hour sucks. They also move people around A LOT. This is the second time this year that my store has no manager.

review_title: Great place for young employees and interns
pros: Friendly and helpful employees. Well-organized with good pay. Most people seemed to have a pretty good idea of what they were doing. Help was always available as needed, very relaxed environment most of the time. Lots of networking opportunities, exposure to different technologies, and organized, sensible business practices.
cons: Difficult to get a full-time position without a degree. Little chance for advancement for anyone without higher degrees. Watched a fantastic employee leave because they wouldn't promote him or give him a significant raise simply because he only had an Associates degree. Other employees followed suit soon after.

review_title: Expect Nothing Fast from Uncle Sherwin
pros:
-I got to work with some people that I enjoyed working with so that really helps.
-The hours really are not bad and most managers will work with you if you need to move the schedule around to get a day off
-Good benefits 
-chances to move up within the company
cons:
-Sherwin Williams  DOES NOTHING FAST!! and I Truly mean nothing. 
-Training is useless because they talk to you for a little bit and then you are basiclly on your own. ASK as many questions as you can because if you mess up it is no ones fault but your own, regardless if you're new or not.

review_title: Not bad, but beware of shady upper management.
pros: Generally good in store co-workers (at least in my district), compared to other retail positions I have held. Customers are generally more engaging than typical retail drones.
cons:
In California, Sherwin-Williams stores are incredibly understaffed. Asked by district manager to increase sales when the store did not even have the capability to serve all customers well. Contractors/customers leave store because of wait.

Store managers and assistants are often expected to work 12 hour days and are forced to choose between taking a (legally mandated) lunch break and making sure the store stays operational.

Most managers quite young. All of the veteran managers in my district were hounded and asked to resign by the new, young district manager. 

BIGGEST problem: that SW allow someone like our district manager to run a district.

review_title: Depends on management and sales reps
job_title: Assistant Sales Manager in Huntington, WV
pros: Was a MTP (manager training position) and then placed as an assistant sales manager in a fairly large store. The pay is good if you are in management, the benefits are great, and even a little bit of paid vacation.
cons:
The store is successful if you have a driven, hard nosed store manager. If you have a store manager that lets employees get away with mistakes and doesn't help develop them, the store will suffer. 

The hours aren't glorious, required to work 44 as an assistant and you will work saturdays and sundays if your store is short staffed.

job_title: Commercial Manager in New York, NY
pros: Good pay, lots of ability to advance if you play by their rules.
cons: Labor intensive back breaking work, a lot of liability that falls on the manager, very little encouragement and a ton of micro managing. They reward unethical behavior and promote morons. They all seem to think they've done it before or they understand, but they are clueless to what their employees go through. You can make more money for a lot less stress and labor most other places. They preach how you can advance, but the district management is full of people who lack the ability to lead properly. Beware of this company, they'll work you to the bone.

pros: Long term benefits,  401k match and pension. Slightly above average salary with the chance to make a decent amount in bonus quarterly and yearly.
cons:
Long hours,  often working by yourself completely for a good portion of the day.  Limited part time help ensuring you and your assistant often to cover store hours. 

Sale expectations are often unrealistic,  double digit increases year over year is the norm.

pros: close to home and decent hours
cons: new part timers do not get any benefits..no access to paid time off..no vacation..no sick days..no health ins,,,no disability...no life ins...  you are expected to be on the job 52 weeks..every week your first year. Meanwhile being paid the lowest wages in the area. We are all part of the "Team" and are expected to help meet and exceed all sales goals however the only ones who receive the compensation [trips..bonuses} when the goals are met is management. ..not even pizza party! there is no locker or a place to hang your coat..no breakroom. Never any appreciation for a job well done.

review_title: Difficult culture to navigate if you are looking for promotions.
pros: Competitive salaries and benefits package. Great fitness facility with knowledgeable and talented staff. There is also a healthy cafe within the building.
cons: At times the corporate culture can be limiting. There is a stifling sense for those who are creative in addition to being ambitious. It seems the culture promotes those who fit a more traditional mold and play a very conservative game. There is a sense of a good old boys network and many employees feel excluded from the opportunity to excel.

review_title: I guess it depends on who the manager is; it’s a great environment, simple and basic work. Not too stressful!
job_title: Sales Associate in Saint Charles, IL
pros: Easy work, not too stressful, laid-back environment, great hours, closes at 7 or 8 depending on what time of the year it’s in, always closes at 6 on the weekends
cons: Can get boring, especially in the winter when it’s slow, from what I hear the raises aren’t that high, really depends on how hard you work and how much effort you put into this job but career opportunities are also pretty easy to get into

pros: The pay is fair once you become an assistant manager or higher.   Work stability. 44 hours as an assistant, 48 as a store manager.  Benefits are okay.
cons: The politics of corporate America.  Hard work and having a good work ethic can only get you so far.. It then becomes a game of "it's not what you know, but rather who you know."   All the stores are running pretty lean, especially the smaller stores.

pros: Good Benefits, Some of the people were ok
cons: Very unsafe enviroment, no ventialtion in the mixing rooms where product is made, Ran out of saftey supplies at least once a month, No vacation time at all, they give it to you but it has to be put in 2 months in advanced and even then it will still get denied. The store I was in needed tanks for their raw materials but instead everything was weighed up by hand, about 1000-2000 gallons at a time all by hand. The turn over rate was about 18 months for all warehouse personel. That includes the CDL drivers.

pros: Sherwin-Williams is a great place to start your career, especially if you are just out of college. They provide in depth training and fantastic benefits, the pay is also pretty good.
cons: The hours absolutely suck-there is no reason that Sherwin-Williams needs to be open on a Sunday, and no reason to be open until 6 on a Saturday. Upper management also thinks they can control everything, and that there always needs to be a manager in every store to babysit because they don't trust their other employees.

pros: Worked as a delivery driver, driving paint, drywall mud and other supplies to construction sites and other Sherwin Williams stores and unloading it all when I got there. Atmosphere was generally very relaxed. Rarely felt pressured to get the deliveries done quickly. Some days had few deliveries and a lot of downtime as a result. Usually flexible in regards to scheduling.
cons: Not great pay considering I'd be moving thousands of pounds of paint and mud a day-$11 an hour. But overall the pay was not severely un-commensurate  with the job.

pros: Great company that is continuously growing and will always have opportunities for advancement. Strongly believe in continuous improvement. Strong culture. Good 401k Match. Hard working, fast paced environment.
cons: Very demanding company, no work life balance. Very political. Poor compensation. Overworked / underpaid. HR is way too powerful.

pros: Good money if you work hard & sell a lot of paint. Great benefits (they match whatever you put into your 401K) & monthly meetings to learn about new products and strategies on how to sell those products. If the store meets their quota, the Asst. Mgr. & Mgr. get a percentage as a bonus of what they make above the quota.
cons: Lack of employees, really long hours (Asst. Mgr. has to do at least 44hrs & Mgr. has to do +48hrs & sometimes is paid salary instead of hourly), & painters are busy during the summer & winter seasons, but not busy during other times making monthly sales unpredictable - taking away from your bonus. If you get hurt, you're kinda screwed because it's a very physical job.

review_title: Management is set up to fail
pros: Opportunity for promotions if you are willing to relocate. 401K, benefits, managers make own schedule.
cons: Store managers are set up to fail. The customer is ALWAYS right no matter what and the company will never have your back. You will be forced to do whatever the customer wants. You must be a push over and willing to take endless crap from customers. Budgets are high and increase every year. If you don't hit budget/sales you will get a poor appraisal regardless of your managerial skills. This will cause you to be stuck in that position or asked to step down.

review_title: a good entry level position...but then what...
pros: good entry level job, and they advertise that.  however, once you get out of the "entry level" range i feel there is a disconnect in career advancement, and a disconnect in salary.  i guess that is part of the problem of working with big companies in general.
cons: as mentioned above, career advancement/development is lacking.  Employees are not rewarded for obtaining advanced degrees either  by promotion or pay increase.  lateral moves are the norm

job_title: Sales Representative in North Atlanta, GA
pros: Great products with excellent customer service.
cons: Surrounded by prima donnas at field level management!  We/they promote individuals who have not performed or suceeded into district management positions without even winning a Spectrum Award!  Those who have stated that we promote based on performance needs to revise their statements.  I'm all for diversity but in order to continue this drive forward we need to put people in leadership roles that HAVE BEEN SUCCESSFUL and have PERFORMED IN THE TRENCHES!

pros: At Sherwin-Williams you can learn some really good practical knowledge about painting. They also offer a really good employee discount on some of the best products in the industry. You'll get a good work out too!
cons: The physical workload can be overwhelming at times....delivering several hundred gallons of paint is physically taxing as each five gallon bucket weighs 55-70lbs depending on the product, and each bucket has to be hand loaded into and out of a van or delivery truck. The pace is frantic most of the time trying to service customers that want their product asap from overwhelmed stores. Advancement can be hard to come by as well.

review_title: My experience at Sherwin-Williams has been great with minor negatives that come with any job.
job_title: Sales Associate in Fort Wayne, IN
pros: Fair base-pay. Flexible schedule and opportunity to increase or decrease hours based on need/want. Clean environment. Healthy social environment (depending on managers). Easy to make good score on appraisals just by coming to work when expected and having a good attitude. Opportunities to move up as long as you are willing to put in time to learn the ins and outs of the company.
cons: - making sure the store is staffed right at all times (the job is specified as part-time for a reason and employees should not be expected to work full-time or close to full-time for lengthy periods of time due to under staff reasons)

review_title: Great company with benefits and good leaders.
pros: Sherwin-Williams is a long established compnay with a great track record for hiring good people. Everyday is different, operating a store is enjoyable, providing above and beyond customer service, full benefits with bonus potential. Overall it is a great company to start at and if you want to stay you can definitely move up. Flexible schedule.
cons: It takes a while to move up the ranks unless you are a real go getter but even then the chips need to fall in the right places. Sales calls, not quite cold calling, but practically. Working weekends and holidays, despite having a flexible schedule.

pros: Not many. Benefit and Salary are above average.
cons: Work/Life balance is not existent. Most MT's quit within first 6 months to a year. Not much opportunity for advancement. No matter what the circumstances that always have the Store managers back. This is a pro is you happen to be a manager, but if you're not it can really make things difficult. Most people who work for the company don't have college degrees so their management skills are a joke. Long hours, work weekends, can't easily move to different locations or departments. As an Asst. Manager coming out of the MT Program you can't choose your placement. I have been commuting an hour for the past year.

review_title: I've been an operations manager at Sherwin Williams floor covering for over 3 years.
job_title: Operations Manager in Little Rock, AR
pros: I have a lot of autonomy with my job.  I have traveled all over the southeastern United States and lived in 3 different cities. There's a lot of room to move up in this company and I started at the bottom moving my way up very fast.  They take care of their employees with chances to earn unlimited bonuses every quarter.
cons: You do work a lot of hours but it's worth it. Sometimes I have to put in a weekend morning every now and then but it's not for long.  The subcontracted installers can prove to be a bit difficult at times.  It's hard to find good, trustworthy installers too but you have to be conscious of that.

pros: Lots of freedom in position, management is helpful IF you reach out first, great pay even at entry-level and bonus structure. Need to increase diversity so minority groups are given lots of opportunities for fast advancement. Pyramid advancement system, over 90% of promotions and jobs are filled within company.
cons: Company offers lots of training but it is designed on a corporate level and is not always helpful, lots of training sessions are pointless. Performance is measured differently in each district, some unrealistic expectations regarding new accounts and sales budget each year. Male dominated industry that makes it difficult to gain respect as a female. Can be hard to leave work at the office. HAVE TO BE WILLING TO RELOCATE TO ADVANCE.

review_title: MTP, Assistant Manager, Branch Manager, Outside Sales Rep
pros: Trained extremely well. Really get a true understanding of how to become a successful business person. You get back what you put into it.  Highly recommend as a first job.
cons: You need to be able to be mobile if you want to advance your career. There is an overwhelming amount of busy work that they dump on you. You are required to do so much non-sense and then expected to grow your book while still maintaining your existing accounts. It is as if you are piling on new business while you are bleeding out of the back end.

review_title: Good first job out of college, great training/structure, not great long-term career wise.
pros: Great training and management/support.  You are given all the tools needed to win and sell/earn bonus money.  If you work hard and do what is asked, you can make some good money.
cons: Lousy hours.  Very much retail hours.  Managers often work weekends.  Not a good quality of life.  All stores are short staffed, could all use an extra employee.  Company is starved for diversity and promotes minorities/woman even if they aren't qualified to put them in visible roles.  If you want to reach upper level management, you'll have to relocate several times.

review_title: Good Pay, Nice Perks, Horrible Clientele, impossible expectations
pros:
Pay is great. 
Vacation is good.
Stock options are amazing.
Sales Reps get Car, Gas Card, Cell phone, company AMEX, and a WORLD OF HEADACHE.
cons:
Clients are unsavory unpleasant individuals of the automotive industry.
You're expected to learn everything in the world about the automotive industry.
The industry is overly competitive to everyone's detriment. 
You spend way to much time stressing, and never have any free time.
Company makes horrible decisions as a whole.

review_title: Sales Rep Decorative Services/ Color Consultant
pros: I loved working for Sherwin Williams.  Great People.  I loved this job
cons: It is a part time position that expect full time accountability.  Lots of driving, too much redundant admin and busy work.  Sherwin Williams is missing the true value of this position to increase sales and support the DIYer as well as the homeowner that is in need of hiring a painter.  They are too focused on sales to the contractor.  This should be a full time position.

pros:
-Flexible schedule (as long as manager, assistant, and third key work together)
-Good benefits (con: company does not match retirement until the quarter after your one year mark)
-Bonuses can be huge (but can and probably will be $0 some years)
-Tons of opportunity for growth (assistant, manager, sales rep, commercial store)
cons:
-Too many hours required (44 for assistant, 48+ for manager)
-Stores frequently understaffed (which means the manager has to work more)
-PTO isn't great until you hit 5 years
-Hard to get out of the retail side and get into supply chain, finance, etc.

review_title: Great way to start your career professional
pros: Match 401k, move up the ladder quickly (started as a MTP, ASM and was a manager within a year), provide health insurance, looks good on resume.
cons: Upper Management was hard to please. Even if you think your store looks great, they will try their hardest to find a flaw. When asking managerial questions, they will suggested you asked other store managers in the area. Overwork employees, only want perfection, treat you like a ghost when you put in your two weeks in. If you go OT (which you will since lack of employees), they will be down your throats.

pros: If your a minority or a woman , then your golden. If you bust your tail and dont get shafted by upper management then you have the ability to make bonus.
cons: NO family life at all. You get hours off not days. You have no staff and are alone alot. All non fulltime employees are completely cut on hours so if you had a good employee they quit because Connor,Davidson, and other big wigs care more about their wallet than employees. LOOOOOONG hours for a paint store. Lack of pay for required job.

job_title: Assistant Store Manager in Rochester, NY
pros: Good business experience, bonuses, benefits are decent, work is routine and repetitive but very easy after you have been in the role for some time.
cons: Upward mobility is a challenge, work/life balance as the company shifts to longer weekend hours to compete with the big box chains, lead generation can be rough having to cold call contractors every week, price of products can make it difficult to sell when there are other competitors and products at a much lower price point.

review_title: Great Job if you don’t have a family
job_title: Retail Store Manager in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Great job security & bonus potential. Great benefits (401k & vacation/PTO). Coworkers are mostly friendly and helpful. Lots of Training opportunities and plenty of growth potential, especially if you’re willing to relocate.
cons: Poor work-life balance for store managers and stores are so understaffed, the morale is low.  Sales reps aren’t held accountable meanwhile managers are doing all the grunt work with little to no regard.

pros: if you're a salesperson at heart, if you happen to be at the right store at the right time, if you're good at work politics, if you love cold calling and pressing customers to make sales and enjoying trying to force relationship on customers, you'll be fine.
cons: Sexual harassment by staff and customers with no help from HR.  No real praise from upper management if a goal is hit, only more pressure to do better.  People who don't deserve to be promoted are (schmoozing works), people who are good at their job get held back for way too long; old boy's club is still very much at work in upper management. Everyone uses everyone else to get ahead. I understand why each store has to buy its inventory from the company so the company ends up showing massive profits from both the stores and the customers of the stores but it just never sat right with me. Shareholders have to be kept happy though.

pros: They pay pretty well considering.
cons: Don't count on the bonus and don't be a victim to the "salary" amount they promise you. Sherwin-Williams bases your pay on what they call "hourly-salary" which means you are required to work a minimum amount of overtime each week. If you work less then that overtime (generally 48 hours/week) then you don't actually receive your full paycheck. Your annual salary is calculated on you actually working that 48 hour minimum work week. Know that going in and you will be much less disappointed.

pros:
Financially strong; promote from within; career advancement opportunities; invest in training and job tools

I worked at SW for over 3 years and really enjoyed it.  I made a difficult decision to leave (on good terms) and start my own home renovation business, which did well for a while but not enough to support a growing family on single income.  I have applied to several positions at SW and not had any luck.  It's a wonderful company and I would gladly work for them again.
cons: Challenging re-hire practices; once you leave, it is next to impossible to be re-hired

pros: Co-Workers! The people you work with at the store level are amazing! There is a massive sense of pride working for a company that is not only as old as as this one, but one that is growing in market share. Each store is run as if it is a small business and that lends itself to a great team environment!
cons: Poor work and life balance, Poor wages for all entry level employees, total disconnect to the company as a whole, they can cut your wages at a moments notice for entry level. As a entry level employee you are not valued by anyone in middle management ( at least that is how it feels).

job_title: Third Key Holder in Cumming, GA
pros:
Decent benefits
Variety of things to learn
cons:
- Any position under Assistant pays very little.

- Over worked

- Unless you have a degree, don't even think about advancing past Full-time 

- College kids get sent on a fast track while the underpaid Full-timers have to teach them everything

- Lead generation is a waste of time 

- A top down system of rewards and praise; Reps,  Store managers and occasionally assistants get all the glory for doing very little of the work.

- Outlandish sales goals for a business the relies on the work that is being done in the location

- City managers and DMs are just talking heads that know nothing about the stores

- Women are given an extremely unfair advantage

review_title: Sherwin-Williams a great place to work.
pros: Sherwin Williams has a positive corporate culture and through education assistance is willing to give you the skills to become what you would like to be.  I have had great mentoring from individuals in the company and that has been invaluable in making career path decisions.  We have some of the best benefits regarding 401K and pension contribution.  Additionally they have excellent training which is provided in a scheduled manner to make sure that everyone has the up to date information.  We also have cutting edge technology which facilitates the sales process.
cons: There is very little downside.

review_title: Wonderful introduction to the world of sales for college student.
pros: The best reason to work at Sherwin-Williams is gaining experience into the world of sales. Managers at branch locations are friendly and well-trained so its easy to pick up on new skills. Work days are diverse, so they go quickly and you get to meet a lot of new faces.
cons: You feel like a very very small piece of the puzzle and it is tough to get in touch with anyone from the corporate offices. Compensation is less than adequate as well.

pros: Benefits, decent pay, and friendly staff
cons: Not enough staff, management pressure from corporate, and a lot of lifting

job_title: Commercial Branch Manager in Ottawa, ON
pros: Great training program for new grads and is a fantastic place to start your career and get experience. Gives you access to various roles in business. As a growing company, there is always lots of room to move-up.
cons:
The downside of a growing organization is that you always feel short staffed and there is a lot of turn-over. At times, very little work/life balance because of staffing.

*One big issue is the level of pressure for sales. It's non-stop! And the company has a very 'American' type of management: lots of tough love. And you're either one of them or you aren't.

pros: Benefits, decent pay, and friendly staff
cons: Not enough staff, management pressure from corporate, and a lot of lifting

review_title: It is stressful at times, but I love working here. Management doesn't get along all the time.
pros: There are a lot of regulars, you get to build a relationship with them and help them with their needs. You know them best and can suggest what product they need for jobs because you have built a relationship and they trust you, they know you will deliver and trust your judgement.
cons: The computer system sucks and takes a while to get used to. It is extremely slow and goes down a lot. There are also a lot of codes and paint numbers to memorize. This job is all about memorization and cramming knowledge.

pros:
Treats its employees well
Promotes from within
Excellent Benefits
Company Culture: although Sherwin is an older corporation, they are not "stodgy" and they value feedback from their employees
cons: "Working" manager roles within IT: in some areas managers are often expected to be "working" managers, meaning both managing a team and being an individual contributor. I consider this normal when a manager is leading a small team, but it can be encouraged/expected of some in middle management which can be more than some people can handle; e.g. managing 15 - 20 people, participating in project planning and roadmaps, dealing with other groups for resources (i.e., typical management tasks), but then also being expected to spend some of your time doing technical work, e.g. software development.

pros: Great Pay. Hires from within. Opportunity to advance if you play their game.
cons: Upper mangement is clueless. Work is delegated down and then upper management takes credit. Often no idea of what our managers are even working on. They claim to care about their employees but are bogged down in antiquated ideals that are making early talent look elsewhere.

job_title: Sales Representative in South Miami, FL
pros: 401k, benefits, company car, people you work with
cons: Program after program to keep up with, making liars and cheaters out of good employees just to keep up with the next program. Methods based reviews. Sales and customer service are not 1st priority of management. People buy from people is an urban legend.

review_title: What happened to the Sherwin Williams we all used to know ??
job_title: PC Sales Representative in Fort Myers, FL
pros: Great benifits, Great co-workers, Good customers
cons: Employee moral at all time low since I have been with the company. District Management micro-manages Reps and Managers to death. We spend more time filling out reports for management than servicing our customers. Area Management has unrealistic goals and expectations. Division is no better. If your looking for stress and big brother then your at the right company.

review_title: What happened to the old Sherwin Williams?
job_title: Assistant Store Manager in Dallas, TX
pros:
Benefits are great!
Co-Workers are great!
Fun and Active Environment!
cons: MICRO MANAGEMENT! There is no more freedom like there used to be. Seem to be caring less about employees and moral. Just not what it used to be and that's why I left. Who wants to work until 7pm for no reason servicing jerk contractors who act like their paint is the cure for cancer. Insane! It's like a 500 pound weight has been lifted off my shoulders since leaving. So happy.

pros: Physically active position, flexible in the schedule. There are some really nice co-workers and customers.
cons: Safety concerns with the amount of weight required to lift and placement of 5-gallon drums (50-60lbs). In some cases the only way of retrieving the 5-gallon drums from overhead would be to place them on your shoulder and find a way to bring it down. Not very easy for a female.

job_title: Third Key Holder in Richmond, VA
pros: Calm environment mostly. You have times it gets very busy and then times when there is really no traffic in the store. The managers and sales reps seem be positive, friendly and helpful most of the time. As part time, it is flexible and work with your schedule. If you show that you are curious and want to work more than you have opportunites to build with the company
cons:
No benefits as part timer
Have to stay under 55 hours every two weeks so may 25-27 hours a week
It is alot of manual labor and heavy lifting, especially on "truck" days making this job not for everybody

review_title: Not as great as it used to be
pros: Great benefits, 401k, 6% of salary  match for stock options.
cons: Middle management is clueless. They hire kids fresh out of college with no experience and make them managers. Kind of a sink or swim mentality. At the store level your competition is other SW stores. It's dog eat dog. It's done that way to promote business growth without having to pay much in bonus. Oh, and if your not management there is no bonus. No incentive to work hard but to keep your job. If your part-time your on the chopping block first when the store sales are down.

review_title: The daily grind of an Assistant Manager
pros: The pro consisted of working in a fast paced environment at times, a learning how to be a great at multitasking. I also enjoyed working with a great team of hardworking associates. Insurance was pretty decent, and bonuses were alright, depending on your numbers.
cons: The cons consisted of being understaffed almost everyday, expectations of upper management for you to do your job, sales reps job, make sales calls, and teach "painters" how to paint. Also, the hours of an Assistant Manager are not good for a person with a family, or active social life. Rude customers and Contractors who feel entitled to preferential treatment. Also, repeatedly lifting 5 gallon buckets can wear your body down.

pros: Great coworkers and job environment. Safety is important to the company and culture.
cons:
The testing lab is often understaffed and overworked resulting in a huge workload. 
Other groups appear to be viewed as more important than the testing lab as they are prioritized over staffing for the testing lab. 
When recognition is given for business wins, no recognition is ever given to testing lab employees. 
In order to progress in the company testing lab employees need to move into other groups. In itself, this is fine, but there isn't a structure or clear path for career development.

review_title: A good place for lifetime employees.
pros: Coming right out of college, SW offers a reasonable salary and excellent benefits.  Being in a smaller store with great people allows for a very flexible schedule and an all around good working environment.  Running a store is just like running your own small business; the results of your labors can be seen.
cons: Bonuses are allocated based on sales increases for the most part.  That would make every other year a good one.  The base salary is not justified without the bonuses.  There are a lot of part time employees working for this company, so if you are looking for benefits it may be a while before your chance comes around.

pros: Decent pay for retail/good benefits. In my experience the people were great to work with and relatively good hours and flexibility during college. You learn lots of practical knowledge about painting.
cons: Cons are the same with many retail/customer service jobs. People can be difficult to deal with at times. Management is micro-managing more and more during the recent years and has unrealistic expectations of what the store associates can get done in a day.

review_title: Over worked and understaffed in the stores.
pros: 401k medical paid vacation opportunity to move up if you work hard and have a college degree.
cons:
Overworked
Managers work 48 hours as a minimum
Understaffed
Fight with hub dispatch to get simple orders delieved
Fight with credit about why charge accounts are locked out
Fight with DM about why you aren't spending 2 hours looking for painters in home depots parking lot
Fight with rude obnoxious painters about things that are usually their fault ie peeling paint isn't the paints fault you put latex over oil! I'm not paging you to fix it. 
Doing 50 stupid pointless sales calls every week because your sales force stinks.

pros:
-If you want to move up, you can.
-You get as much out of the job as you put in.
-Stores work on a team mentality which makes the job fun (if you've got a good team).
-Good employee discount.
-They tend to hire from within.
-Upper management has respect for in-store sales associates.
cons:
-Moving up generally requires a BA.
-They tend to hire from within, but not all the time. Sometimes Mangers-In-Training were poppin' fresh out of college--and had ZERO experience with paints, chemicals, and customer service. 
-Terrible color choices for store interiors--makes advising customers on color combinations difficult. Makes us look like we don't know what we're talking about.

job_title: Senior Hyperion Developer/Analyst in Cleveland, OH
pros: They will send you to Kscope every alternate year.
cons:
- Lack of good managers, managers are not good listeners & lack overall ability to manage the team,includes micro managing at all levels
- Higher IT Management doesn't care if their managers are not doing good & will ignore your complaint totally
- The more you work in this company the less credit you wil get & all the credit will be given to person who know nothing about the system
- The culture in this company is to not to work hard, if you want to work hard & grow in your career this company is not for you
- If you are looking to file for your immigration paperwork, they don't have goo lawyers, so your H1-B, Green Card can get denied at any stage, IT management will not take any stand on this.

review_title: Strong Industry footprint but has become a telemarketing position
pros: Strong Financial performance, Gaining market share, enjoyable customer relationships. Decent pay if budgets are obtained.
cons: Many District managers and Vice Presidents of sales who practice negative reinforcement management styles as they like to keep you "shaking in your shoes" as a means of motivation. This combined with a subjective performance appraisal process can make things much more stressful then they should be.  Micro Management, too focused on lead generation forcing 100+ cold calls per week. Long store hours. Has strong focus on hiring women and minorities not necessarily the best candidate.

review_title: Pros and Cons, just figure out what is important to you
pros: Good benefits and salary, most everyone you work is sharp and know what they are doing. Some managers are really great and care about you even if you don't work directly for them.
cons: Some management simply got promoted to high, and they are ineffective, don't know how to motivate, and let things slip through the cracks because they can't manage their emails/voicemail/calendar/etc. Work/Life balance can be tough, with some people being sent abroad for 2 weeks to a month or longer.

review_title: Store Manager On the Way Out
pros: Salary is decent but is low to incentivize hard work for the potential bonus. (Keep in mind, Cost of living is not considered much when they calculate salaries. You will find a manager in Arkansas making the same salary as a manager in a major Californian City.)
cons: Hours are extremely long and staff is kept very lean so everyone is spread too thin. No fulltime employees other than management so turn over is HIGH!! Expect to see a revolving door or a whole lot of people chasing a carrot on a stick.

pros: Great 401k, can advance as quickly as you want. Constant training and learning opportunities. Pay is just above average.
cons: No family feel at all, your biggest competitor is your co-worker. Very clique culture, if you are new it does not matter what your accomplishments are you won’t fit in. Makes it difficult to move to a new position knowing you have to prove yourself over and over again.

review_title: Sherwin Williams is an incredible company to work for.
pros: Sherwin Williams whole-heartedly believes that a good work-life balance is important for keeping employees happy and hard working. They have worked hard to make sure my personal life also is balanced so that I can stay happy and successful in my job. sherwin Williams is also great at promoting managerial positions from within.
cons: One challenge is that the paint stores are open long hours, 7 days a week and sometimes this means hours of overtime for management of the stores. The opportunities for growth also seem to be less for part-time employees.

job_title: Store Training Manager in Atlanta, GA
pros: Relaxed, autonomy, good bonus potential if you manage/increase sales, for the most part good opportunity for promotion, good training, multiple celebration events throughout year, good benefits, excellent stock performance,
cons: not alot of resources to motivate store associates, no break rooms, no real lunch break schedules, managers can be overworked and not paid for overtime, not alot of option outside of store or sales going through mtp, a little bit of old school mentality in regard to selecting candidates- some people in positions for the wrong reasons, certain departments are very very inefficient and hurt other parts of the company, lack of investment/attention in store associates,

pros: Benefits and hands on work.  It's not just a desk job.
cons: They tout high levels of customer service but do not back it up with their hiring otactices. Low pay outside of management positions, only part time hours (28 hours a week) for those outside of management,  which results in high turnover for those positions. Store management is then picking up the slack resulting in 10-12 hour dsys with no break or lunch at times due to the inexperuence of the new staff because of the turnover, in addition to being open 7 days a week.

review_title: A good company, on the whole, with job-security. If you perform above expectation.
job_title: Store Manager in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Great first career experience in managing all aspects of one's "own small business", dynamic work environment where no one day mirrors another, advancement opportunity, continuous learning environment
cons: Business culture that fosters no acceptance for divergent ideas from its subordinates, extremely long hours

review_title: They have good benefits but they are not very organized.
job_title: Branch Operations Manager in Chattanooga, TN
pros: This company has good benefits and good salaries for the amount of educations that is required. They do not require anything beside a high school diploma to get into management but it is a lot easier if you have a bachelors.
cons: All that the company cares about is sales. Operations almost seems like an afterthought. Store management is seen as a baseline sales force, being required to do the job of a sales rep and manager. There seems to be little to no accountability for how the actual sales reps do their jobs.

review_title: Assistant manager position review of 7 yr experience
job_title: Interior Architectural Designer in Atlanta, GA
pros: Great company to work for, they take care of their employees and offer 401k, stock plans, benefits and compensation for disability depending on how long you have worked for them.
cons: Slow growth in the company but it is guaranteed growth. Depending on where you live or what district you are working in higher positions may or may not be available. Current employees have a lot of competition within the company and with outside applicants as well

review_title: Beware of the Job Fair Propoganda
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: Good sales and management experience for a future job.  Ability to make good bonus money.
cons: There are too many to list so I'll highlight a few.  As a store manager they require 48 hours per week for your salary which is low to begin with.  If you don't have an assistant manager you may be working upwards of 70+ hours with no overtime.  Once you figure out how to interpret your P&L you find that every imaginable expense is passed down to the store pushing that carrot out just a little farther.  Once you realize that some of the national accounts are paying below store cost for material you realize that your bonus is subsidizing market share.

review_title: Must be able to follow rules
pros:
*Company culture is amazing once you are in management/sales rep level
*HUGE opp for women and diversity
*There is no gray area with what expectations are
*Benefits are amazing
*Great training
*It's easy to love what you sell
cons:

*Unrealistic sales goals/new account goals
*Management is stressed
*Product issues and limited company support!! Chunks in paint and poor inventory control from corporate

*Work/Life can be challenging. I was 9 months pregnant and expected to work at the store alone. Pregnant again as a sales rep, and had to work on maternity leave to maintain my customers

review_title: Beware of the Job Fair Propoganda
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: Good sales and management experience for a future job.  Ability to make good bonus money.
cons: There are too many to list so I'll highlight a few.  As a store manager they require 48 hours per week for your salary which is low to begin with.  If you don't have an assistant manager you may be working upwards of 70+ hours with no overtime.  Once you figure out how to interpret your P&L you find that every imaginable expense is passed down to the store pushing that carrot out just a little farther.  Once you realize that some of the national accounts are paying below store cost for material you realize that your bonus is subsidizing market share.

review_title: A great part-time gig for college students
job_title: Wholesale Product Specialist in Worcester, MA
pros:
Flexible Work Schedule for students
interpersonal skills development
Inventory and customer lead generation database exposure
Great people working in the store group
A great place to grow professionally
cons:
Physically tiring due to being chronically understaffed. 
A somewhat toxic corporate structure stemming from upper management's fundamental lack of understanding regarding day-to-day operations at the store level and
a corporate desire to cut costs that overrides any value that upper management might have for the employees that actually generate revenue for the organization.

job_title: Assistant Store Manager in Detroit, MI
pros: Flexible schedule, start with vacation time, health benefits, good management experience, opportunities for advancement, varied tasks, not a desk job
cons: Weekends, holidays, retail environment with uneducated contractors, physical labor (50lbs+ not uncommon).  A full truck to unload of pallets stacked with paint.  Advancement is possible but takes longer than they let on.

pros: Worked in Stores Division and had many great mentors and leaders.  Enjoyed opportunity to be a Training  Store Manager and share their great training programs.  Women's Networking Group is sign of vision and support from upper management/CEO.
cons: Advancements are upheld by unrealistic sales budgets that don't mirror current market conditions in your area.  Your hard work and methods do not count towards promotions, only making your numbers.  Also annoying to deal with contractor pricing schedules.

job_title: Sales Associate in Green Bay, WI
pros: Extremely organized company who take pride in their employees. One of if not the single leader in the retail and wholesale paint industry. Great benefits and fantastic resources for employees in the careers and personal lives. They build from within if you are drinking the blue and red "Kool-Aid".
cons: Typical corporate structure. Sales associate, Assistant Manager, Store Manager, Outside Sales, Sales Manager, District Manager, Regional Manager and so one.

review_title: Good job and good place to learn skills
pros: The work is very easy once you've been trained, You'll learn a lot about paint and home maintenance that you can use in your own life, Co-workers were always very friendly, Boss treated us all equally and never put acted like they were above us.  Even part time workers can enroll in a 401k.
cons: The first shift started at 7:30 am, so you need to be a morning person or work the evening shift.  5-gallon paint containers are fairly heavy and can be a pain to stack in the back storage.  Our store dealt with a lot of contractors, who all came in first thing in the morning with very large orders.

review_title: Great for college student wanting to gain experience
pros: Increases customer service skills.  Teaches basic business skills.  The company is incredible when it comes to promoting within so if you stay with them even after the internships you can make a great career.  Sometime there are nice customers.  Even though there are some negatives mentioned in the cons if you can tough it out you will be fine.
cons: Low pay.  Most of the contractors are awful to deal with.  Understaffed.  Its a retail environment to everyone it difficult to work with.

review_title: An incredible company that I am proud to be a part of.
job_title: Hybrid Sales Specialist in Baltimore, MD
pros: You are challenged everyday and are taught how to run a business. They are very employee oriented and promote mostly from within. They treat their employees very well.
cons: Positions are not always available for advancement.

pros:

-flexible hours
-  plenty of opportunity to advance 
- you do get the freedoms to more or less run your own business without a large amount of oversight

-advancement is about 90% luck of the marke you were chosen to be in

pros:

review_title: Great company to work for even through these tough times.
job_title: Assistant Manager in Pembroke Pines, FL

cons: Hours can be long at the management level, can sometimes be hard to get days you want off.  People are traded fairly but some managers can be difficult to work along side with.

review_title: Glass ceiling stalls SW's opportunity for growth and sustainability in a troubled market.

Managements desire to promote MEN to power positions, because they have a higher risk of losing them then women. Managements inability to utilize technology and inability to mandate that their employees utilize technology, either because they don't know or don't care. Inability to use the correct resources.

review_title: Great company, fast paced, with room to grow.

review_title: Good for corporate people looking for advancing opportunities.
job_title: Outside Sales Representative in Montreal, QC
pros: Salary, other incentives, schedule flexibility, market innovations, Market leader. When you begin, all is good.  Great tools, Crm, calendar, web portal etc.
cons: Lack of support. Numbers only matters. Confusing management. No recognition. Make you feel like you are not worthy. Lots of work to be done in terms of territory/segmentation precisions to avoid gray areas where reps compete each other instead of working together.

pros: 401k, benefits, advancement to sales rep,  bonus
cons:
Sherwin is good at getting you in as an MTP making you think your getting paid well. Once you get to Store Manager and realize the amount of time and effort your putting into your business you see your very underpaid. There will be many times when you will work 12 hr shifts by yourself with literally no one else in the stores. This makes it hard to use the bathroom or eat a lunch. They built a culture where your expected to deal with it which I was not ok with. I went nearly 2 months working 50+ hours because I had no assistant but was lucky enough to have a reliable part timer where's some managers have gone 5 months working 70+ hours 7 days a week. As you are by yourself your still expected to run a million dollar business with upper management hounding you about numbers. Sherwin is starting to lose many good people because of this. It's gotten to the point upper management is holding meetings trying figure out why they are losing these people when in my opinion it's not rocket science. 

Bonus structure is nice but depending on your store, location, and the state your store was left in by previous management, it can be very hard to obtain any extra bonus and may take up to 2 years before you see anything. With the base they pay you being very low this can make it seem like your working for nothing.

Also the understaffing has gotten so bad they take almost anyone with any degree to just to fill a spot. My assistant was the farthest thing from business minded and told me she did not like sales which showed through her quality of work and attitude for the 10 months we worked together. This method of take what you can will eventually start bringing in the wrong type of people causing the good people to leave.

pros: The company has good vertical growth for careers and offers great benefits. The company is willing to assist your growth, as long as you are willing to work hard and ask the important questions.

pros: The Managers at the  Store were great they did a great job in training and expressing their desire to see their lower level employees succeed and they did a great job in showing their application to your hard work and dedication to the job. pros:
Great company to work for.   Good benefits which include pension (almost unheard of these days), 401k and health insurance.  Their stock had doubled in recent years and continues to grow which is good for stabilty.

review_title: Great College Job and  Management opportunities available in other cities after graduation.
pros: Work schedule works great with school schedule.  Management was awesome regarding questions from new employees and they were very patient during the learning process.  Very active paced work days.
cons: No air conditioning in the warehouse, and during the summer days I would recommend bringing an extra SW shirt. No room for growth unless you find another location to find an Assistant Manager position to fill.

job_title: Sales A in Hanover Park, IL
pros:
-Great manager
-Delegation of tasks are very communal; there isn't a huge overbearing pecking order and the manager would often do the very same things we did
-Very inclusive place to work
-Managment assigned responsibility
