cons: Corporate politics are very bad. Not fun to do checklists all day. Company is solely focused on sales. Part time employees are expected to make introductory sales calls... that's not how a company should try to produce sales. Hire more sales reps in the field instead of drowning out your employees and burning them out. Overall employee attitude across the company is disgruntled employees. Do more with less.

review_title: Can't imagine a better Company to work for....
pros: Strong, ethical, employee dedicated Management.  Great Leaders, Co-Workers, morale.  Financially sound.  Great advancement opportunities (no glass ceiling).  Competitive compensation.  Generous 401K and Pension Plan.  Technical leader.  Superior quality products.
cons: Must be willing to innovate, work hard,  maintain standards, have high morals, and contribute whatever it takes to achieve personal and Corporate goals.   Not really a CON... probably key to what makes this Company great!

job_title: Sales Associate/Key Holder in Atlanta, GA
pros: I love the benefits that a part-time employee receives. Vacation time based on hours worked per week, 401k match up to 6% starting on a year anniversary at the company for a kick start to your retirement portfolio, Holiday pay 4 hours for days worked on and free flu shot all provided by the employer. Not to mention 40% off everything throughout the year and 50% employee appreciation discount 4 times a year for family and friends makes it extremely desirable for family members of employee. I love the people I work with and Company party is pretty good too. The customers become so familiar as you may see them pretty often. It is the best job I have every had for part-time. Calling another store is always an option. People are always willing to share their knowledge of product and application methods/ computer things.
cons: As with any job there are bad things. The one bad is if you work the weekends you won't have much ability to call the hotline. There are resources but it is really hard to find them. You really rely on other stores with more exp to guide you. It helps but they can only do so much for you. You have to learn A LOT of stuff. I speak fluent Spanish so it comes in handy but in my area if you do not know Spanish you are at an extreme disadvantage. Most of the contractors in my area sent their painters to pick up the things and their English can be pretty weak. The learning curve is extreme. I mean EXTREME! I have never had a job with such a large amount you had to learn. There are so many things you have to learn!!!!! TRUST ME!!! I can't stress that enough!!! If you can't learn about the product this is not a good job. I also want to add that some people have complained about a max of 26 hours a week. I couldn't imagine trying to live off of 26 hours a week. Also 5 gallon buckets can be heavy. Not a problem for me because I use it as my workout for the week lol. I also heard it is hard to become a full timer with this company especially at a slower store. I have no desire to become full-time so I am an exception.

pros: The people you work with in the store usually make going to work more enjoyable.
cons: Say that they promote within but only want to promote men. Terrible customers that wine about everything. Very few people in store, basically run it half the time although only 2 people get paid what the job deserves (manager/assistant). District management in the Eastern Division, at least, is not professional and has made me want to leave this company.

job_title: Customer Service Specialist in Hillsdale, NJ
pros: Great salary, making $14.15 after a few months(started at $10.55, became a keyholder after 5 months, started working in Oct 2015), loads of training at the district office to make sure you know what you need to. Everyone in other stores is willing to help if you have questions or anything.
cons: Its tricky learning the industry, there arent a whole lot of people who know about paint right off the bat. There's a lot of information you need to learn as soon as possible & it puts some pressure on you as an employee.

review_title: One of the cheapest company you'll ever work for
job_title: Sales Representative in New York, NY
pros: Stock and 401 k, great benefits plan
cons:
The downside to this company is the wage is very low for the work that is required of you. a lot of unreal expectations in Metro NY.- Down 4 years in a row
Understaffed stores.Training lacks a hands on application approach. Store management appears to be overwhelmed with the demands from clientele which prevents them from truly investing time into their employees.

review_title: Great Opportunities, If You're Willing to Give
job_title: Assistant Manager in Saint Louis, MO
pros: The professional coatings industry is highly competitive. There is always room for growth in your professional development and career. As long as you are willing to relocate, there are endless career options for you at Sherwin-Williams.
cons:
Running a successful store requires your time. I am not against putting in 50 hours a week, but Sherwin-Williams just does not make it seem worth it. With mandatory overtime every week, I am still only bringing home a $43,000 annual salary.  Being placed as an assistant manager in a store that has seen (slightly) declining sales in the last few years, I see very little bonus quarterly payout to aid my salary. Which is unfortunate, because I am still putting in crazy amounts of overtime to run a (roughly) $1.5 million dollar store due to a bare minimum staff.  The time I put into my store, is not worth what is being offered to me.  I can't tell you how many times I have had contractors ask or say to me, "Why are you the only one here?" "Where is your help?" "You must be the most hardworking girl I know, you're ALWAYS here." 
I fully understand that I have the power to move up in the company and get myself out of my current situation. But it's a gambling game. There are so many factors besides management that drive sales down in a store. Do I want to put in endless hours for a mediocre salary at best? I've seen the brightest people get burnt out at Sherwin-Williams. And it's not because it's a challenging career.  It's because there is little fulfillment gained to the job we are pouring our lives into.

pros: Good. company benefits. Camaraderie among store and rep level staff.
cons: Always understaffed. Work more hours for less pay when you get into store management positions. A “what have you done for me lately” company.  If you have a degree you will be under payed entering the Management Training program and the pay does not get that much better unless you move all over the country.   They do not value time with the company with opportunity. Upper management has the philosophy that everyone is replaceable.

pros: Honestly benefits are great, fantastic health care program and 401k options.
cons: First off- building is awful, cockroaches, dust, horrible air quality. Second- zero consistency in management. No one is held accountable and always blame the little guys... typical daily life. Normal to be threatened to be fired over being 1 minute late. HR incompetent, don’t bother reporting anything it gets ignored. A bunch of corporate drones trying to make them selves look better by belittling their subordinates. Especially because they can’t show their work to make them stand out because they are incompetent.

pros: They give great benefits to part timers, and make a competitive salary compared to other similar companies. Also have a great organization. Company is very well run overall with a great business plan.
cons: Not sure how often part timers get a raise in salary, and sometimes the leadership in management is lacking. It is a paint store after all, very blue collar in the end.

review_title: A company that will ride, suck your energy, pride, and constantly tell you to fo better for 40 grand a yr!
pros: Good Vacation hours, great benifits.
cons:
Continously work more than scheduled hours and asked constantly not to have overtime!
Staff has become slimmer and slimmer over the past year! 
SW wants more concentration on DIY but doesn't give us the staff to do so.
SW needs to check in on managers more, some are driving the stores and employees to the ground!
Completely physical job, pretty much you stand for 10 hours a day and when its busy there is no eating.
The two worst things: cutting staff but adding on responsibility! Revieiws are based on the mishaps of having a bad manager!!!!

review_title: SW is great company and has excellent benefits for its employees.
pros: Many long term tenured employees and excellent pension and 401k matching.
cons: Too many programs that the employees all have to buy into. Also, not enough FT employees and would rather hire PT to save on paying benefit.

pros: Decent benefits and pay, work can be pretty fun, most managers are fairly laid back and you don't feel like you're a slave to work and being forced to work sundays or nights like some other part time jobs
cons: Lots of hours, not having to clock out for lunch is nice, but you are expected to stop eating and work if need be that way, i would sometimes rather just clock out for lunch but nobody really does that here

review_title: Great... for the right kind of person
pros: Fast-paced; Possible rapid career progression; good benefits; great people; good company values
cons:
Need to be a specific personality to get promoted-- upper management wants a specific mindset and has little use for extra skills or novel approaches.  Must do things the company way.
Compensation / Bonus structure promotes mediocrity in long-term sales performance.

pros: They were amazing to me and flexible with my schedule. I loved the customer interaction and the feeling that came with helping people finds and make the right paint.
cons: They make you take a lot of training courses to really make you understand the material. It is a big corporation so tiny in store issues take a while to really get figured out and settled.

pros: Benefits, job security, bonus incentives at management level.
cons: Women and those with College degrees advance quicker, Division managers/City managers demand more and give you less to work with. If you don't agree there's a big chance you will be on a list to get terminated.

review_title: Great experience at a powerhouse of a company!
pros:
I am a part time sales associate with Sherwin Williams and I have a positive outlook on the company.
Flexible consistent hours
I feel close with my coworkers 
Company has a good reputation in the industry and customers recognize that.
Overall a great place to work.
cons: Not too many cons here. The training was a little rushed and underdeveloped in my opinion. I don’t always feel like I fully know what I am talking about when discussing products with customers, but that will come in time.

pros: I like to work with my hands and help out people, so this position suited my goals. I worked in warehousing, inventory. Flexible hours, plenty of opportunity!
cons: I believe if you are looking for a part time job or a career, it is important to be wary of    who you are working under as it affects how fast you progress and the environment you work on.

review_title: This is NOT a good company to work for.
pros: They pay well and have decent benefits, so if money is all that matters it might not be a bad fit.
cons: There is ZERO life/work balance, they expect you to live to work for Sherwin especially if you are in management. They have realized they can run a store all day with 2 employees doing the work of about 10 so that will never change.  We also have to work with archaic equipment, which can sometimes be dangerous. For example, forklifts that are over 13 years old still being used in stores.

review_title: I was a Sales Associate and now I’m a color consultant!
pros: Always room to grow!  I’ve only been with the company for 2 months and have already been promoted and moved out of the store, which is tough for a female at times.  You get to do a little of everything.  You work hard for Sherwin and they notice and they’ll reward you.
cons: The POS is outdated and can be really intimidating for someone who has never used it before, especially when they want us to get ecommerce orders.  Also, the slow shipping of products.

review_title: Short-staffed, too many "blowout sales" make for tough time working there
pros:
Downtime when not inundated with customers

Ok pay for a part-time job
cons:
Sherwin Williams is obviously very desperate these days so they see the need to have these ridiculous 30-40% off sales constantly. Our store is short-staffed usually, which makes for a nightmare of a time. 

Corporate is completely out of touch. Our City Manager is a moron who sees the need to have to interview a part-timer (which we desperately need) who should have been hired a month ago. Since then a few employees left and we're left holding the bag. 

The pay is horrible for what you're asked to do especially when you're thrown to the wolves during these nightmare sales. 

If you work there get ready for horrible weekends in the summer because it's just too busy to even enjoy working there. 

Corporate is clueless when it comes to selling Duration paint. It's way overpriced and quite obvious why they need to give it away every other week in these sales and promotions. Otherwise they can't sell it. 

For myself it's a part-time job on the weekends, but I don't see myself staying very long because it's becoming more and more of a stressed-out and hectic environment. It's way too hectic for $9.60 an hour.

pros:
The work within a store setting is a great first experience.
The pay is good for students.
Staff within the stores are great people, and a lot of fun to work with (most of the time),
cons:
Long and tough hours, especially during the summer.
Technology is 15-20 years behind the times.
Skills do not transfer well to other industries.
Gap between stores and district.

review_title: Good position for recent college graduate, but true advancement appears to stop at the level of store manager.
pros:
While the stores are open 7 days a week, the hours are during the day. 

Management was always accommodating to requests for time off if given in advance.

Store staff usually consists of less than ten people, which led to a high level of team work and camaraderie.  

While there are some difficult and shady contractors to work with, most are very kind and good to work with.

Health benefits and vacation time are nice.
cons:
After four years of service and positive yearly reviews, my hourly salary increased only $1.50.  The compliments are few and far between when times are good.  The negative feedback comes quickly at the first sign of low sales.  Increases in responsibility (promotion to 3rd key) only led to more work with no increased compensation.

Everything seems to be based solely on quarterly performance, which leads to a constant one year up, one year down, one year up, etc.  All positive results seem to be forgotten when sales go down.  Judgment is often based on the numbers and not the potential causes for the numbers.

Benefits gradually decreased over the course of my tenure.  The matching 401k contribution was lowered when the economy started to falter.  The full-time associate bonus was eliminated at the beginning of the year.

Official company training consists almost solely on watching CDs that often contain out-of-date information.  There is limited literature on product information outside of data sheets.  Most of my practical product knowledge came from the contractors themselves and their personal experience.  

Little information is given on competitor products or promotions.  We were constantly told to promote our products as being better than the competitors but given no resources to use to back up that claim.  Occasionally, we would be sent a short fax on responses to give over a consumer product rating.  This made it hard to honestly answer questions customers would ask about how our products compared to other companies.  When selling a product that is more expensive than almost all other competitors, employees need to be given specifics on why the product is better.

Store management appeared to have little real control over the operation of the store.  All major decisions (staffing, customer pricing, complaint resolution) had to be approved by the District Manager. There was often an adversarial relationship between stores and the sales rep.  Rather than reaching equitable solutions, more emphasis was placed on who was to blame for the situation.

The hiring process for part-time help is incredibly slow, which made it hard to quickly fill in staffing holes during busy times.  

Upper management is constantly trying to push the competition with big box stores, which has led to an increase in store hours and operating days.  While this does benefit stores that are in immediate proximity to big box stores, it lead to spreading out the same business over the increased hours in other stores.

While there are opportunities to advance, at least to the store manager level, you must be willing to relocate wherever they need you to go.  Outside of that, most movement in the company appears to be lateral.

review_title: Decent, though certain aspects of it are fustrating.
pros:
If you average 20 or 25 hours a week you get some paid vacation, paid holidays and time and a half on holidays if you work, which more than likely will be the case. 

You are always busy, so it makes the time go by fast.(except in the dead of winter in the midwest it becomes pain-stakingly boring,) 

I actually enjoy helping people choose colors for their homes, though to a certain extent. After an hour and a half of discussing whether they should paint their kids room "fun yellow" or "petunia pink", I have had enough.

I have a baby and am nursing and manager is really nice to allow me to only work short shifts so I am not away from him for long periods of time.
cons:
If you work part time you are basically stuck working the crappy hours, nights and weekends of course. 

Some customers, as it is in all retail, can be very rude, strange, and downright annoying. 

Pay is decent, though I have been working there almost 5 years and I have a 4 yr degree in Interior Design, so in acutality I feel like I should be making more. However, the likelyhood of me finding a better job in this economy is dim, so I take what I can get.

Part-timers work just as hard, if not harder than management and we see no bonus whatsoever. 

Having to put away the massive load of paint that comes in weekly is ton of work. Your back will get sore and you will be exhasted at the end of the day. (Though you will get buff)

Despite what many people may think, there is a TON of information you need to learn regarding paint. You need to know the answers too because you will constantly be asked random questions by customers. This is why I despise the "Ask Sherwin Williams" slogan.

You need to be able to multi-task well and work fast. And when it gets super busy and you are working by yourself on a sunday which is always that case at our store, it can get really overwelming and stressful. Especially when there is a line of 8 people starting at you waiting for your help.

review_title: Looking back, I am pleased with my experience. But, at the time, I definitely had a few complaints.
pros: Great benefits, Normal hours, Decent starting pay
cons: The job I had was billed as "Office Technician" and was considered to be a glorified administrative assistant, yet I was making fairly intricate logistical decisions on a daily basis. Furthermore, the position had a very low salary cap for what the job responsibilities were.

review_title: Life getting harder at the store level
pros: Sherwin Williams has a lot of great employees that you become friends with as well as colleages.  A leader in innovation in the industry.  Stock price is going up, 401k matched up to 6% for now.  Good benefits and pay overall.  I also enjoy working with most of the contractors as well.
cons: Hours are getting longer for store employees.  Since October 2010, the paint stores have extended hours to be open 14 hours more a week with little or no help to cover these hours and the same expectations on managing overtime down to as close to 0 as possible.  Also, holiday hours are longer as well for store employees.  Not for upper and middle management, or credit offices, or anyone in corporate.  They have implemented a new delivery hub system, taking vans from individual stores and putting 3-5 vans at a "hub store".  We have no guarantees on when paint can be delivered to a job unless we use our personal vehicles.  Worst of all:  THE BUDGETS.  You can have a great year with huge jobs that you won over a competitor and get lots of pats on the back for a job well done.  The next year?  They expect that, plus around 17% more.  If you don't hit it, you get treated like you suck at your job.  Evidence?  Almost my entire district got a "4" (needs improvement) on their evalutations.  Did Chris Conners and John Morikis get 4's with no pay raise?  Not according to the annual statements.

pros: The pay and benefits are good, but are replaceable. Fitness center and cafeteria. Vacation time.
cons: It is run like the 1940s boys club, very hard if you are a women. There is no work life balance if you are a working mom. The traffic and parking are horrible in Cleveland. I don't think the company has the culture of always doing the right thing for the employees. Promotions are selective.

review_title: Good at first, but gradually getting worse.
job_title: Part Time Sales Associate in Orlando, FL
pros: The coworkers are great, I've made a lot of friends over the past year and most everyone (in the store) helps out and does their part. The pay isn't as low as most entry level part time jobs.
cons: Wayyy too understaffed for the work were expected to do. I'm a part timer doing crazy hours and working a ridiculous and chaotic schedule; if I need to do something personal or for school I have to schedule it off or I WILL be scheduled that day no doubt. Any management position in the store, even the assistant sits back and watches us do the work, they basically just sit back and have a great time and ring people up. For the type of physical work were expected to do, we need to be payed way more. Management has gotten cheap with hiring and only visit the stores to rearrange some shelves and intimidate us. Used to be a good corporation when I was a kid, now all they care about is profit and raising prices, which are insanely high. Try explaining to a customer why one gallon of paint is $50, and the cheapest we have is $36. I'm sick of being yelled at by customers for prices. Also, if you want to move up in the company you'll have to move to another district. No room for growth in Orlando.

review_title: I have worked with the company for 4 years, and I plan to add many more on to that.
pros: It's close to home, one of the best, if not the best paying job in my area.  Great benefits, solid hours, 40+ a week.  In the 4 years I have been with the company, I have held 4 different positions, this company is great if you wish to succeed and move up in the company.
cons: Work can become repetitive at times.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Good exposure to different aspects of business, telemarketing, stalking competitors, product kmowledge, customer service skill advancement, sales, teamwork, and multitasking.
cons:
Long shift hours
No schedule flexibility
If your a single parent, forget about needing to leave and tend to your kids, your in a male dominated industry and they expect you to have other people raising your kids so you can slave away and miss out on precious time.
Chemical exposure
Bad environment- no accommodations, back braces, face masks, safety glasses when dealing with harsh odors, chemicals, and lifting all they want you to lift.
Merit increases are small and you don't get bonuses unless you are management.  
No respect from coworkers who are high school kids, and management does nothing to promote enthusiasm and encouragement in the workplace.

If your pregnant, or are a woman of child bearing age, AVOID THIS COMPANY. High discrimination and terrible HR department.  They will treat you as a liability and force you to leave or get terminated unfairly.

pros: good 401k plan and decent benefits, along with competitive salaries for full-time workers and adequate bonus programs when individuals are able to produce.
cons: Culture varies greatly from area to area and even within areas, as with most places, it is as good as the people you work with.  However, many times a culture of hyper-competitiveness to a fault is present, which leaves individuals at the mercy of middle management.

pros: Excellent performance bonus structure; generous vacation time based on years of service; room for advancement; preference to hire from within
cons: Terrible work/life balance; lack of talented people in entry level positions; broken staffing model; low wages for part time employees; part-time work only unless management; lazy do-nothings are often left in position for years because internal policies make them difficult to oust

pros: Sherwin Williams is a great company as they have lots of opportunity for growth and they offer management great benefits. The best way to get in is through their Management Training Program and in the Orlando are you can get promoted to management within a year or two.
cons: If you take a management position you cannot be afraid of sales pressure. You have a budget to attain and if you do not attain that goal you will have to explain why in front of your bosses and colleagues. If you enjoy sales however, that can be a great motovator.

pros: Company has excellent products to sell.  They have many knowledgable, professional, and helpful salespeople, willing to train and mentor new employees.  Clean, well-organized stores.
cons: Long hours and a poor work/life balance.  Disconnect between upper management and store personnel.  Staffing so minimal, there was often only 1 salesperson working alone in the store for hours.  POS system is complicated and difficult to master.

pros: Good pay if you have a degree, decent benefits and vacation time. Good place to begin a career if options are slim. 401k 6% match is great.
cons: Long hours, lackluster upper management, numbers driven, easy to "luck your way" into a good year and get "golden boy" label. No positivity unless budget is achieved, poor communication, and lack of opportunities for advancement.

pros: Medical/401k benefits. Met a some really good people that I hope to stay in touch with. Gives early career skills to those fresh out of college. Flexibility for sales reps in their schedules. The job itself is not glorious.
cons: I left on good terms, but my overall observations of the company from treatment of employees(especially the Charlotte District) as a whole is a very old school mentality, top down hierarchical authoritative management style. Manage by fear and selfish priority rather true employee management and training. Appreciation was never sincere and never acknowledged except at National Sales Meeting, one night a year. Lack of acceptance/adoption of change in current business philosophies. Pay is below average including bonus structure. Lacks typical sales organization's motivational rewards. Very slow in adapting to tech changes, and still has a blue screen in stores. Did not have a one on one with manager in field for 18+ months. It was obvious that the sales mgr had other priorities to his existing territories rather new ones. Upper management is way out of touch with store operations. Offer very little help, empathy, or reward to under-staffed stores. Placed fear in employees if they talked about Valspar acquisition. Yes SW is acquiring Valspar. Dont tell the world if you don't want them to talk. Good luck Valspar employees. There's a reason the company dropped in rankings in places to work. Preach safety, but don't offer ways to work around it. Once tried to help an employee to report an injury and got scolded because the district has the highest injury rate in the company. Its ibvious they hire certain employees straight out of college for their figure and looks. They'd brag about "hiring diversity." I support diversity, but you still have to give the best applicant the job.These are just a few of my thoughts and ones that my peers shared with on many, many occasions.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Winnipeg, MB
pros: My manager was amazing. I had a good crew to work with. Getting to know regular customers. Sometimes we would get lunch.
cons: Corporate refuses to raise pay, refuses to change employee status to full time even when they're working 40+ hours a week, refuses to fund appropriate safety measures even after having an inspector tell them what is necessary.

review_title: Driver for 4 years in two cities
pros:
The job was flexible. I started in my hometown and after 6 months there I got accepted into college and the manager was able to help transfer me to a store in my college town. I worked at the college store for 3 ½ years and they were always very accommodating and understanding when it came to school work and working around odd schedules. The best part as a student was that I never worked past 6pm and had weekends off. By the end of my time there I was working Monday-Thursday with a three day weekend. 

The work was pretty easy, drivings easy, stocking and moving paint wasn't the best but it could've been worst.
cons:
I worked three summers which is the worst time of year. All the students leave and every apartment and dorm needs repainting which could means me as a driver (and MAYBE a second person if your lucky) is responsible for moving roughly 4,000 gallons a week to job sites and most of the time it is done by hand or will be loaded into the truck as a pallet then unload by hand into storage containers or garages in the heat. 
Sometimes the painters or maintenance people will just stare and smoke cigarettes as you do all the work and complain that they weren't given a heads up about the delivery even though they made an agreed date of delivery with a Rep and it's you, the drivers fault that the paint showed up. 

Your hands will get kinda rough and your shoulders, back, knees will hurt from bending, lifting and jumping in and out of box trucks. We've had temps who would quit after a day in the summer because it's that bad. 

I started off at $9.50 and worked my way up $11 which isn't that bad but having to deal with idiot drivers on the road, inconsistent paperwork from store to store, and the physical labor of it all should be paid more. Like starting at $11 and working on up from there.

pros: Everyone who works in the company really takes pride in the history and the products. We all know that when it comes to coatings we are the industry professionals regardless of the project scope. That is all thanks to the training the company provides. They instill values in you that make you work harder, longer and drive for results more so than any other company I have ever worked for. This is an asset if you choose to leave the company.
cons: They pay is horrible for the amount of work that is expected.  As a PT Sales Associate you are expected to do lead generation, open cash accounts, open charge accounts, create and build relationships with contractors in addition to maintaining the store, shipping and receiving and bucking paint around all day. It is a expectation to help the store grow all the while you reap no benefits from it. There is zero incentive for out performing as a entry level PT Sales Associate.  You also do not get any of your breaks. As illegal as it is, managers either don't schedule breaks for you or have such little staff that it is impossible to sit down let alone eat on a 10 hour work day. This company says they take care of their employee.. well they do not take care of the people who sell their products for them. They pay their associates horribly, they over work them, expect them to go above and beyond with zero incentive and on top of that you hardly ever get to sit down and eat during a shift. They also do not provide decent places to sit and eat. I have commonly had to stand and eat using a paint bucket as a table. Please, if you value your physical, mental and emotional health do not work for this company.

pros:
Working for a fortune 500 company
Great Benefits
For a retail job, it pays you well for the position, and one of the better paying jobs coming out of University/College (especially if you have a useless degree)
Not a desk job, you are able to get up and move about.
 There is some down time, to sit down and relax. 
Get to communicate with contractors, DIY customers, etc.
cons:
AM's are required to put in 44 hours a week and Managers are required to put in 48. Thats the minimum if you have a properly staffed store. Without a proper staff in place, you can easily be doing up to 60 hours a week/ 7 days a week.
The company is the definition of a "the customer is always right" company. No matter what, the customer is always right, regardless if they scream, yell or curse at you. Upper Management will turn a blind eye to those issues just to retain business.
Must be willing to travel in order for promotional opportunities. The company will pitch you on the fact that they like to promote from within, which they do, but you are stunted when you reach a certain level ( Assistant Manager---> Manager----> Sales Rep). It is very hard to get a position in a corporate desk role or in district management. 
No matter how successful you are instead of praising your work, company will always push you to increase sales and examine what you are doing wrong instead of highlighting your strengths.

job_title: Part Time Sales Associate in Cleveland, OH
pros: Most people in the company are friendly and willing to help/teach new employees. Daily operations require even part-timers to learn/develop professional sales skills, which the management team is mostly helpful with.
cons:
At the end of the day, working at Sherwin is a retail sales job; there are plenty of mislead, annoying, and downright mean customers who want to ruin your day. As a part-timer, shifts/hours fluctuate wildly, and at $10.50 an hour, you will absolutely need a second job to live off of. 

Many managers and sales reps of the stores are nice and helpful, but they are all under the same pressure to sell, sell, sell. District managers are constantly trying to raise the ceiling on quarterly profits and that stress trickles down to the part-timers. According to internal stats (and personal experience), part-timers account for upwards of 40% of company revenue, yet get paid half of what the managers get ($10.50 versus $20+ per hour). At many locations, the duties of a part-timer blur very much with those of the store managers. In this way, it's good to earn such solid sales/networking/management experience, yet it's frustrating if it doesn't lead to promotion. 

Furthermore, promotions from part-time positions to Management trainee positions are an enigma; some kids get put straight into the program (earning $18+ an hour) while some really awesome and knowledgeable employees have to work for 2-3 years before being offered the management trainee position (if at all). In this way, most employees agree that nepotism and kissing-up to the district manager is the only quick way to get promoted, rather than exemplary performance.

In conclusion, working at Sherwin is only worth it once/if you become a management trainee or higher (thus earning $18+ per hour). Otherwise, regular associates end up with way more responsibilities than should be expected, which, again, is only worth the time if you're willing to kiss enough tail and wait long enough to get the promotion.
